All Reviews

  1. Replaced a very inexpensive 'vibrator' type brush with very difficult to replace heads with this technology on the recommendation of my dental hygenist. Very pleasantly surprised that it works so well particularly in comparison to what I have been using for several years. Very pleasant against the gumline and seems to be doing the job in keeping the plaque from returning. Will have to see how things go over time, as I have a lot of trouble with plaque build-up and staining as I'm a 'full pot' coffee sipper. I've never thought I was good at lasting the requisite / needed time period for brushing, but this is so pleasant that I find it's not enough to go through only one timed circuit. I'm depending upon the brush rather than watching my own clock or watch, but it seems to be shorter than 30 seconds per quarter section. Anyway it's no big deal to just click the button to take up where I leave off. Also really like the convenience of removing the head section and cleaning with the ultraviolet compartment. So far we're all good! Other than initial cost being tough for those of us who've never gone this route before, I can't think of any reason not to recommend it to everyone...
  2. I did a lot of research before purchasing this - watching online reviews and comparing it to other Sonicare models. In the end, I'm really glad I decided on this one.<br /><br />It has a super-sharp design, for one. Although that's not something I ever thought I'd want/need from a toothbrush, it's nice.<br /><br />But more importantly, it cleans like crazy! Other reviewers have said that it feels like your just got back from the dentist. And although it's not THAT intense of a feeling, it's as close as you're going to get at home.<br /><br />I usually keep mine on the Gum Care setting. I like having a little extra time at the end if I feel like some of my teeth need a bit more attention. But the Refresh setting is great if you want to freshen up before going out somewhere.<br /><br />I only wish it gave you the option to choose only compact brush heads. The larger brush head always led to toothpaste splashing everywhere. I prefer the compact, hands down.
  3. Very cool product, keeps my teeth so clean, even my dental hygienist suspected I was seeing someone else, hahaha! Still running well after almost 2 years of having it, with no issues at all. Easy to clean too!
  4. I have been using the sonicaretoothbrush for a few years now and short of going to the dentist you will not be able to get your teeth thus clean. Previously when I had seen the sonicare toothbrush in my Dennis office I thought it was just another way to sell you an expensive upgraded toothbrush. But after using it for several years and not having a single cavity in that time and getting compliments from my dental hygienist I can't see myself going back and using any other toothbrush. My only complaint is that after a few years the rubber on the handle has started to peel off and if you allow water droplets to dry on the inside of the sanitizer it will discolor the mirror coating.
  5. I've been using this product a few years now. Gotta say how much I love it. Battery life is exceptional. Travels well and overal 5 star product. Will definitely buy a sonicare again in the future.
  6. I love the toothbrush. The UV sanitizer to keep bacterias and viruses down, in the tooth brush, is a great idea!<br />The battery lasts long enough for 2-3 weeks trip. It's great! Compact with a good travelling case!<br />All in all, I am very pleased!
  7. After a week of use of Phillips' HX6972-10 'FlexCare Plus' kit I offer the following observations:<br /><br />1) It appears to perform its basic function (bushing teeth) well (far better than a regular toothbrush);<br /><br />2) As emphasized by one reviewer, the hard plastic end piece to which the actual toothbrush is attached vibrates furiously and has the potential to be genuinely hazardous when it contacts teeth at certain angles (i.e.: if the brush end is not carefully positioned while the toothbrush is in one's mouth). Therefore, this might not be great for inattentive toothbrushers or smaller mouths.<br /><br />3) If you use an HX6972, make sure that you put the toothbrush into your mouth before turning the device on: Toothpaste will fly off the toothbrush before it reaches your mouth if you turn the brush on before it's in the mouth!<br /><br />4) Don't wear good (or dark colored) clothes while using this thing: Since the mouth has to be open while using the device (to keep it properely positioned and to avoid having teeth shattered - only slight exaggeration - by the vibrating plastic) some small amount of toothpaste and/or saliva will splatter while using it: I had to mop up a dozen or so spots of toothpaste from my bathroom mirror (and once a shirt) after each of several uses. Eventually, and with good fortune, you will master its operation (hopefully).<br /><br />5) Wait for respectable pricing (list price is outlandish) and rebate opportunities.<br /><br />Other than as noted above; probably a useful device to keep teeth extra clean, and a neat toy.
  8. I bought this toothbrush for myself. It works great. But I think the price is a little bit high. I like it.
  9. Excellent product. Works as advertised. Holds charge for good length of time. Super cleans teeth. Highly recommend this terrific product.
  10. Great toothbrush that is worth the price! If you consider how much whitening products and cavity fillings cost, you can save yourself a lot of money by purchasing equipment (such as this electric toothbrush). While I do use mine every day, I don't use all of the brushing modes. The only negative thing I can say about this toothbrush (but it's standard now on almost every electric toothbrush) is the fact that it has a built in timer. This shuts it off after approximately 2 minutes, which almost always isn't enough time for me to cover all the surfaces/areas (but that's probably just the meticulousness/OCD in me, more than anything else).<br /><br />What you need to know about this toothbrush (in a nutshell):<br /><br />- lasts about 1.5 weeks from a full charge<br /><br />- requires some getting used to if you're new to Sonicare electric toothbrushes (loud vibration if the hard part of the brush touches your teeth)<br /><br />- it does a great job<br /><br />- brush heads can be bought for a reasonable price in packs on Amazon<br /><br />- sanitizer works very well<br /><br />- if you have multiple brush heads, you could potentially share this one unit with a spouse/significant other (completely up to you)<br /><br />- YOU SHOULD BUY IT!
  11. Without hyperbole, I can honestly say it gets your teeth as clean as a hygienist at the dentist, and quickly.
  12. 2014.11.23 Update: this product is fantastic. It continues to work as expected. Original: This toothbrush works great for my wife and I. It is surprising how well the charge lasts and how well it charges wirelessly. The toothbrush has many options on how to brush. Perhaps the settings change too easily as i frequently find the setting changed after my wife uses it.
  13. My dentist noticed a difference in my gums after using this toothbrush for a month. Cleans well, has almost too many brushing options but makes my mouth feel clean and stimulates my gums. My wife and I use it every day and when it wears out. We'll get a new one.
  14. Avoid this product like the plague. Two have died on me in less than a year and a half. Others have had the same problem with this model dying after a relatively short time.   15. worked great then started turning on and off on its own no it wont start at all. dont have paper work to retun
  16. first of all, the electric plug did not fit usa electric outlets.<br />second, there was an import tax, on the item, i think the tax was about $20.00 which i paid.<br />the emails from the south korean company assured me that if i bought an adaptor plug, that i could use it in the usa.<br />the south korean company emails were nice, but they didn't understand that i didn't order what they sent me, and i didn't want to buy an adaptor so i could use it.<br /><br />i sent it back...i think the return postage was about $30, which i paid.<br /><br />amazon reimbursed me for all the outlays, and refunded the amount i paid for the toothbrush.<br /><br />but i was unhappy, because i had to settle for a lesser toothbrush from a local store.
  17. Bought this 3 years ago and it died last month. It did a good job cleaning, but with the price I paid, I would expected longer life. My previous Oral B lasted more than 8 years. I wanted to give it another try so I picked up a basic mode 2 Series Plaque Control last week from SAM's club since I thought I don't need all the bell and whistles on the high end model and I could just save some money by sticking to the basics. Boy I was wrong. The cheaper model makes awfully loud sound and it can't clean -- turns out that the motor is very weak, they used cheap plastic instead of rubber around the shaft, which made the little vibration sounds horribly loud. I will have to return it and say byebye to Sonicare -- I am going back to Oral B.
  18. This product is incredible. my teeth feel so clean after each use and it is worth every penny to me.
  19. Dentist told me few years ago this was the best way to protect your teeth and gums. Didn't get around to buying. Dentist was so right that this is light years ahead of normal tooth brushing for cleaning teeth and keeping gums healthy. Fact that it has a method for completely sterilizing brushes made me take the jump to buy. Insructions easy; the pause system that tells u when u have spent enough time on a section of your teeth makes this so user friendly. Lasts long time between charging--nearly a month. Be prepared for irst time use---it will tickle like crazy. Switch it to \\"sensitive\\" for a few brushings and by 2nd brushing I had no tickling sensation. You immediately adjust. Moved from sensitive to normal seeting within a week. If a family---you'll need more than one power wand, since if one of you is traveling, who gets custody of the Sonicare becomes an issue! After I bought this, saw some sets come with multiple wands.
  20. The differences between this model and the \\"older\\" Flexcare are minimal, that is probably why all they did is add a + to the end of the name. But there are a few differences between the two.<br /><br />1. Most notably is the \\"new\\" look. It has a cleaner appearance with most of the front being a dark chrome look, also instead of the green led's, it has a backlight behind the selected brushing mode.<br />2. Gone are the 'Go Care' and 'Max Care' and in their place are 'Gum Care' and 'Refresh' mode. They do exactly what the other one did except for one important change on the 'Gum Care' mode which replaced 'Max Care (which is why I picked the new one over the old) '. Instead of having a 3 minute routine with 45 seconds each quad (30 normal + 15 massage) for a total of 3 min; they now have it where it goes 30 seconds each quad with an added 1 minute at the end for 'problem areas' which is broken down into four 15 second intervals.<br />3. 'Different' color, looks very similar - its 'Soft Sky Blue' instead of 'Medical Blue'. Basically bluer color than the old one which was more of a green color.<br />4. Supposedly lasts longer - 42 2-minute brushings, vs. 20 2-minute brushings of the old one<br />5. Case is now hard plastic instead of the soft case that comes with the old model<br /><br />There is also a few changes in what the battery display shows with its charge but I'm not going to go into it that far with this review. I decided to upgrade from the Sonicare Elite as I was getting tired of seeing the nasty gunk that would grow inside of the handle. It was time to get a new brush head so I decided to go ahead and get a new brush while I was looking around. Overall I think it has been a good decision as this brush shouldn't need the constant cleaning of the old one and I like the new 'Gum Care' routine. So if wanted to know the differences, there you go, you probably now know more than you wanted about a toothbrush. If your like me and wanted to know at least some of this, it should help you decide between the two. I hope this helps you out.<br /><br />UPDATE 10/2011 - After using my brush multiple times daily for more than 1.75 years, the head of the brush handle was starting to make loud noises and had become \\"loosened\\" from the pressure of brushing (I would consider myself a hard brusher). Luckily it comes with a 2 year warranty. I called them up and was sent a replacement brush immediately, excellent customer service! The brush I received is perfect and I have been using it since. Great product with great customer service to back it up!<br /><br />UPDATE 02/2014 - I have had the replacement brush for nearly 2.5 years now with no problems whatsoever.t some of this, it should help you decide between the two. I hope this helps you out.<br /><br />UPDATE 10/2011 - After using my brush multiple times daily for more than 1.75 years, the head of the brush handle was starting to make loud noises and had become \\"loosened\\" from the pressure of brushing (I would consider myself a hard brusher). Luckily it comes with a 2 year warranty. I called them up and was sent a replacement brush immediately, excellent customer service! The brush I received is perfect and I have been using it since. Great product with great customer service to back it up!<br /><br />UPDATE 02/2014 - I have had the replacement brush for nearly 2.5 years now with no problems whatsoever.
  21. I have been using the predecessor Philips Sonicare FlexCare for 16 months (and this brush for a week) and love the brush and the company. When I had trouble with my older brush this summer, I easily reached a company rep on the phone and they promptly sent me a replacement (registering the brush made it easier).<br /><br />I work at a dental school and Sonicare is the brush we use and recommend. Of the Sonicare options, the FlexCare Plus offers the most features.<br /><br />Although one is capable of cleaning their teeth just as well with a manual toothbrush, people are less likely to brush for the recommended two minutes when using a manual toothbrush. Furthermore, the hand motions required with manual brushing are painful and aggravating for people with carpel tunnel or arthritis. This brush also has an automatic shutoff after two minutes so you don't have to time yourself.<br /><br />If you are not used to using an electric toothbrush, this brush will gradually increase the intensity as your gums get used to the extra stimulation. You can also manually change speeds and vibrations but this is a questionable blessing as you may be prone to accidentally push these buttons while brushing.<br /><br />I recognize that a number of reviewers have commented that sanitizers are unnecessary. Here's my take on the subject.<br /><br />Your toothbrush can harbor a variety of germs capable of causing illness and even reinfection with the same disease (see dentalresource dot org slash topics25 dot htm). Your risk is increased if your brush is kept near your toilet or if your home has roaches.<br /><br />The American Dental Association says \\"data do not demonstrate that they (sanitizers) provide a specific health benefit\\" but they do recommend ways to keep your toothbrush germ free and a sanitizer will help.<br /><br />I surveyed the head of dental hygiene and five dental professors, including one charged with monitoring the school's sterile environment. All of them agreed that a sterilizer was unnecessary for home use but half of them used one anyway.<br /><br />At the least, putting the brush head in the sterilizer is easier than using boiling water or bleach water. While it is inexpensive to replace a manual toothbrush every couple of weeks, we tend to keep the $13 electric heads for a couple of months, putting them at greater risk of harboring an infection.<br /><br />Ultimately, the cost and convenience of a sanitizer make it a reasonable addition to good oral hygiene regime.lf of them used one anyway. At the least, putting the brush head in the sterilizer is easier than using boiling water or bleach water. While it is inexpensive to replace a manual toothbrush every couple of weeks, we tend to keep the $13 electric heads for a couple of months, putting them at greater risk of harboring an infection. Ultimately, the cost and convenience of a sanitizer make it a reasonable addition to good oral hygiene regime.
  22. I am thoroughly impressed with the Philips Sonicare FlexCare Plus. I was somewhat skeptical about what to expect from a teeth cleaning system promising such great things, and the price also caused me some hesitation. On the whole, however, this toothbrush delivers as advertised. MODES: There is no shortage of brushing options here. The Sonicare has five modes: Clean, Gum Care, Refresh, Sensitive and Massage. After reading the directions and making several trials with each one, I still can't quite figure out why Refresh is on here. There appears to be no distinction between Clean and Refresh, and the directions only indicate that the Clean mode is designed for a two minute brush, while the Refresh is designed for a one minute brush. The difference is also subtle between Clean/Refresh and Gum Care. Nothing wrong with having too many modes per se, but it almost seemed like Philips just wanted another selling point by offering five modes. The other Sensitive and Massage modes, however, demonstrated their unique value. Notably, the Sensitive option offered a much gentler brushing, and the Massage option was a nice change of pace along the gum line. As a side note when using any of the modes, and you will probably learn this within five seconds of your first use, make sure the toothbrush is in your mouth before turning it on. As I found out, a brush this powerful can and will spray toothpaste everywhere. PERFORMANCE: There is no denying that my teeth feel cleaner after each use of this toothbrush. The Sonicare does all the work, so there is no actual \\"brushing\\" involved on your end. The brush head is designed well. It gets into all the crevices and does a great job between the teeth and on the gums. I discovered one interesting thing upon reading the directions. The Sonicare comes defaulted to setting called Easy-start. Basically, this feature starts you off with a gentler brushing experience for your first use, and the power gradually builds throughout the first week (i.e., 14 brushings). The directions say this feature is there for you \\"to ease into the Sonicare experience.\\" If you don't feel the need to ease into a toothbrush, don't worry, there's a way to turn off Easy-start. Further, I could not detect any difference in intensity during my first 14 brushings, but this may be the point of the feature. Also, I noticed that while brushing, the Sonicare sometimes stopped its buzzing for brief moment. After looking this up in the manual, I learned that this is the toothbrush's way of letting you know it's time to move to a new part of your mouth (e.g., after 30 seconds it's time to go from the front of the lower teeth to the back of the lower teeth). DESIGN: The handle of the toothbrush has a nice grip. The brush head is small, but I find this a good thing, because anything bigger would be a nuisance once it started buzzing in your mouth. The front of the handle will highlight which mode you are in, and it is very easy to tell which mode is highlighted. You can only switch modes when the Sonicare is turned off. UV SANITIZER: The UV sanitizer takes 10 minutes, if that. The brush head fits right inside the compartment on a small peg, and the door shuts firmly even though there's no latch. You push a button to start the cleaning process, and the UV light will turn off automatically. Also, if you open the door at any time during the cleaning, the UV light will immediately shut off (tried it). This is a safety feature. The brush head will come out slightly warm, but only slightly. I like this feature. I can't imagine what a hotbed of germs a toothbrush is, and the UV light kills 99% of bacteria and viruses. CHARGERS: It takes 24 hours to give this product a full charge, but once it's charged, you won't need to do it again for a long while. I've heard this from other reviewers, and I can tell you from my own experience that after a week of use, I still have full bars (3 of 3) showing on the display. The device comes with a travel charger as well, but you may just want to leave it in the drawer if you're only going out of town for a week or so. You can also leave the toothbrush in the charger after each use, and once the device is fully charged, it is designed to draw only minimal power from the outlet. The base of the charger also has a way for you to wrap the power cord under the device. This just allows you to shorten the amount of cord you have exposed to view. I first found this annoying because it's not that easy to fit the cord into the grooves in the bottom of the charger. Once done, however, it was nice to get the excess cord out of the way so it wasn't bunched up on the counter top. BOTTOM LINE: I know this product is expensive, and I know there may be more bells and whistles than you're looking for on a toothbrush, but I think it's worth it. Dental health is important, and we too often take it for granted.
  23. This is my first review on any product and I wanted to be sure I rated this one 5 stars. I have been using a Philips Sonicare toothbrush for the past 7 years and this one by far is the best one to date. It offers options that are wonderful like \\"refresh\\" that I use between meals that isn't your standard 2 min of brush time as in \\"clean\\" that you would use morning and night. There is \\"gum care\\", \\"sensitive\\" and \\"massage\\"...see what I mean by options! Now you may not use all of them, but Philips offers them to us for the folks that will. Now the brush sanitizer is a fantastic addition to this system. I have no way of really knowing if it is working or not, but it appears to be doing its job. When turned on you see a light illuminate from inside and omit this blue glow. My son loved my toothbrush so much that I purchased him the Kids Sonicare toothbrush which I would rate 100 stars if I could. My son loves brushing his teeth and for a 5 year old what more could a parent ask for with dental hygiene? Thank you Philips as you have done it again.

I had a problem of placing to much pressure while brushing using a conventional toothbrush, but using the FlexCare I've noticed I use little pressure and can feel better results, thus eliminating the possibility of eroding my enamel. It's hard to come off the hip with this amount of money, but I highly recommend it for your dental health.

  32. I purchased this toothbrush about 3 months ago here, I was a bit weary of the price since i had never used a sonic toothbrush before, but I figured it was worth a shot. I have been more than happy with this toothbrush. My teeth have never felt cleaner. The UV light works well, it also adds an added benefit of helping the brush dry quickly. The gumcare mode is really the main one I use, it combines the 2 minute clean with a 1 minute cycle for your gums. The 1 minute gum cycle has it's own quadpacer as well, which is kind of neat. My only partial complaint is that the brush heads do need to be replaced quicker than a normal manual toothbrush, but this was something I expected going in. The head gets much more wear and tear with how fast the brush moves. I got about 2 months out of the head before it needed to be changed. Of course if you think about the extra 1 minute gum cycle adding an extra 1/3 time to the brush cycle, it kind of makes sense that the brush would wear out an extra 1/3 faster, i.e. 2 months instead of the typical 3. Of course if your looking at this brush the head replacement is probably pretty trivial seeing as how, well, if your willing to spend this money on a brush, purchasing replacement heads should not be an issue. I definitely will never go back. I was completely sold on this brush within the first couple days. Great product Philips!!!

  37. இ Fuzzy Wuzzy's Summary:<br />ѾѾѾѾѾ Highly recommended with warm fuzzies!<br /><br />I have been using the [[ASIN:B000UK2W4C Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush with Sanitizer]] for the past three years, and even though that product is still available, for a slight price increase, the FlexCare Plus adds incremental improvements to what was already a very nice toothbrush. There are improvements in all areas compared to the previous FlexCare model, from the better cleaning modes, to the nice plastic travel case, the improved battery life that lasts twice as long as the old model, and the slightly quieter sound during its use.<br /><br />As with the previous model of the Sonicare FlexCare, I cannot verify the efficacy of the UV Brush Head Sanitizer to kill bacteria. On both the old and new FlexCare model, I actually rarely ever use the UV Sanitizer as I find that just thoroughly rinsinig the brush head after each use and letting the brush head thoroughly dry before I use it again is sufficient. Back in the \\"old days\\" when I was still using manual (non-electric) toothbrushes, I have always alternated between two manual toothbrushes, thoroughly rinsing each brush after use and letting each totally dry in between use, and I never had any issues with hygiene from contaminated brush bristles (heck, doorknobs, public drinking fountains, kitchen sink sponges, and shaking peoples' hands can carry more germs.)<br /><br />I did notice that while the previous FlexCare model gave you the option to purchase the product *without* the UV Sanitizer ([[ASIN:B0013TVEWA Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush]]), for their newer FlexCare Plus model, there is no option to purchase a version that lacks the UV Sanitizer (which, as with the previous FlexCare model, would also make it less expensive). I wished that Philips kept offering a version without the UV Sanitizer since the recharging base is more compact without also including the UV Sanitizer unit on it (so it occupies less bathroom counter space and is far more compact to pack into luggage).<br /><br />As with all electric toothbrushes, you should not push and press the toothbrush too hard into your teeth and gums, both to keep from damaging the tooth enamel and gums and also to help the motor not work so hard. My previous Sonicare lasted for almost six years before its motor finally died.tizer unit on it (so it occupies less bathroom counter space and is far more compact to pack into luggage).<br /><br />As with all electric toothbrushes, you should not push and press the toothbrush too hard into your teeth and gums, both to keep from damaging the tooth enamel and gums and also to help the motor not work so hard.   38. I ordered the product described on this page: HX6972/10 What I got was the HX6992/10 This is apparently a newer model. I have been unable to find any technical information on the HX6992/10 while I was able to find technical info on the HX6972/10. While the price here was good for the HX6972/10, it is about $40 higher than for the HX6992/10 at other places. The Philips web site is pathetic. The most recent version of the toothbrush they show is the HX6950. Also under specifications, they list the frequency as \\"31,000 brush strokes per minute\\". This is deceptive as frequencies are always measured in cycles/second, so the correct number is 517 strokes per second. So this toothbrush is sonic, but not ultrasonic (ultrasonic is for frequencies above 20,000 cycles per second). This is the second time I have been mislead by an Amazon product. At least this time the switch was to (as far as I can tell) an equivalent product. (last time it was a cheap knock off). I gave 4 stars because the toothbrush I got works well, I just wish the marketing matched the product.

I like the battery life indicator, the sanitizer and the multiple modes for use. I would prefer it to be a little less powerful in the sensitive mode, but other than that I have no complaints and as I have mentioned after getting used to it it's not bad. As for differences between this and the elite, the main difference I've noticed is the difference in use options, the stronger brushing action and the fact that the battery on the flex care+ last a lot longer between charging. I've left it off of the charger since the initial charge and it still has battery life after almost three months of use. My husband has the flexcare model and is pleased with it so far I don't notice a lot of differences between the flexcare and flexcare plus when it comes to performance. I've contacted sonicare customer service a couple of times about rebate information. If you register the brush you get an e-mail coupon for money off a second toothbrush and/or replacement brush heads bought after the date of the e-mail. So far they have been very helpful and even sent free brush heads to make up for some mis-information they gave me about the rebate forms. Overall I'm pleased with both the toothbrush and the company.

  50. I've used a couple other Sonicare toothbrushes in the past (the kind that unscrew into 2 pieces & expose the vibrating magnets) & have always loved Sonicare. This one is the best of the ones I've used so far. Before this Flexcare toothbrush I changed over to Ultreo (sonic & ultrasound waves) which, like this one, was a 1-piece unit with no parts to rust from water exposure. It was similar to Sonicare but different & took some adjustment to get used to. It lasted me several years before the internal battery died completely & I needed a new brush...enter Flexcare. (I had also tried the Oral-B rotating brush but it annoyingly tickled the nerves in my nose.) This toothbrush is even more slender than the previous, more lightweight & easier to use. It gives me 30-second intervals on the 2-minute brushing timer & several cleaning options (though they all feel the same). I'll never go back to a manual brush ever again - there's no clean like a Sonicare toothbrush gives. I keep mine in my shower caddy & the battery carries a charge for a long time before I have to recharge (a month perhaps?). This kit comes with an extra brush head & other accessories. It's a bit of an investment cost-wise, but absolutely worth it! Since there are no exposed internal parts to rust from water damage, I expect this one to last much longer than my original Sonicare (which unfortunately only lasted a year & actually cost more than the one I have now).
  51. My 6 year old Elite 7500 (NiCd batteries) finally wouldn't hold a charge so I bought this Sonicare model to replace it. To cut to the chase, it is not as powerful as the Elite 7500. That is, the vibrating action is not as strong...the FlexCare without the ramp-up feels like the Elite with its ramp-up. I've made sure that the Plus does not have its ramp-up (on charger base, hold power-on button until one beep). The brush head is firmly placed on the toothbrush itself. Don't think I'm doing anything wrong...just doesn't feel as strong.<br /><br />That's not to say the Flexcare doesn't clean well...I think it does. I asked my dental hygienist about the difference (she had both models right there) and she thought she had also noticed the difference in power, but no difference in cleaning ability. Still, it's a bit of a disappointment.<br /><br />Advantages are the UV sanitizer and the Li-ion batteries. My hygienist has me spending much more time brushing my teeth than the \\"quadpacer\\" says...in fact I spend about double the time, that is, 4-5 mins total, twice a day. So the extended battery life is great. Also the brush heads are cheaper than for the Elite series. Never could bring myself to throw out the two magnets on each of those, so always pried them off the brush base and keep them in the garage. The newer brush heads are less wasteful.<br /><br />As for all the other modes (massage, refresh, etc) I don't use them and hope Philips doesn't keep adding gimmicky features which don't add real value. I would rather they allow one to set the cleaning time desired, instead of fixing it at two minutes total with 30 seconds a period.<br /><br />All-in-all the FlexCare Plus continues the great Sonicare function. Would I still buy this model, knowing it's not as powerful? Yes, and if I knew I wouldn't have that slight disappointment! Hence this review.

  61. The product was great, until it stopped working after less than a year. Once it's out of warranty there is no possibility of repair and all they give you is a coupon worth 15% off of their online store (which sells products at approximately 15% higher price than Amazon!). Here's the online chat I had with them: Welcome to Philips Chat, you're chatting with Sally. How may I help you? Sally: Hello Scott Scott: Hi - my Sonicare Elite 9000 (XH9882) has stopped working Scott: I assume it is out of warranty, but how do I get it repaired? Sally: What is the exact issue you are facing with the unit? Sally: I'm really sorry about the inconvenience and I'll try my best to help you with it. Sally: Could you confirm the exact issue you're facing with it? Scott: It won't turn on and when we put it in the charger no lights come on that indicate it is charging Sally: Okay. Sally: May I also have the serial number which is a 6 digit number that immediately follows the HX model number. Scott: 071015 Sally: Thanks. Sally: When was it purchased? Scott: 2010 Sally: Which month? Scott: December Scott: but I don't have a proof of purchase because it was a Christmas gift Sally: Okay. Sally: Scott, how long did you charge the unit before turning it on? Scott: It's been sitting in the charger for the past 6 hours and no lights are coming on Sally: Alright. Please place the handle in the charger and charge it for 24 hours before turning it back on. If the handle still does not stay charged, my best suggestion would be to purchase a new Sonicare. Sally: Unfortunately, our Toothbrushes are not repairable. Scott: are you kidding? Sally: If you decide to purchase a new Sonicare toothbrush, to help offset some of the cost, I can offer you 15% off your total Sonicare purchase along with free shipping at our Philps online store. Sally: no Sally: Our records show the unit is out of warranty. Scott: I am really offended Sally: I'm sorry about that.. However, since it isa gift, I doubt you have a purchase receipt. Sally: Have you registered the product? Scott: these things aren't cheap. Sally: I can understand that..
  62. I cannot say enough good things about this marvel. I absolutely love it and have noticed that I brush my teeth more frequently and for much longer.
  63. It worked well initially, but in less than 2 years the base of the brush where it charges became yellow; the rubber that seals the device/battery was torn and as a result, the brush started to malfunction. I contacted Philips, but they refused to replace it because it was out of warranty. For the price, it should be better quality. I must say that I took meticulous care of the toothbrush, wiping/drying it's base after every use.
  64. I was in the process of having peridontal treatment due to deep \\"pockets\\" (5-6), so I bought my FlexCare Plus toothbrush at the recommendation of my dental hygienist about 6 months ago. My dental check ups dramatically improved (\\"pockets\\" are now 1-2). My daughter was wanting an electric toothbrush for Christmas, so I bought her one and she loves it! Teeth feel so much \\"slicker\\" and fresher than ever before! I also love being able to sterilize the bristles with the UV light. Well worth the money!
  65. I have never had an electronic toothbrush before and was a little leary of ordering one so expensive. I had done quite a bit of research on them and the benefits of the electronic toothbrush. I couldn't be more happy with this product...so much so I bought one for my wife, who is very particular, and she loves it as well. The battery charge lasts about 2 weeks brushing 2 times per day. The automatic timing let's you know you have spent enough time in each zone of your mouth. The gum control function works great and provides an extra minute of brushing. Your teeth and gums feel real clean when finished. It's difficult to say if the sanitizer works but we use it once a week anyway. Haven't used all of the functions yet as it is only 3 weeks old. Very happy with this product and would recommend it to anyone. Money worth spending.
  66. Contrary to 20 years of trial and error experience, I took a chance and spent almost $200 on this toothbrushing system. Best thing I ever did for my mouth, teeth and gums. Period. It makes brushing easy. It makes brushing effective - really clean teeth. Awesome product that actually delivers. I am also using the UV sanitizer frequently.

  72. I have a throat problem and brushing my teeth can cause me trouble. The heads on this product are small enough for me and wow does it clean. Especially on the 'gums' setting. After just a week of using it I got 'applause' from my hygenist.
  73. So far, so good. We had used an older version of the Sonicare toothbrush for years, and although it did an excellent job of cleaning our teeth, it had some drawbacks. This version rectified those issues, such as the head of the handle had a hollow well that could get nasty if you didn't clean it religiously every day with a sanitizing product. This model has a different type of connection that is much more sanitary. Plus there is a UV light in the base for sanitizing the brush heads. There are some suggestions that I would make to Philips if they are listening: We had to purchase two of these rather expensive models because there is only one charge spot on the base and it only comes with one toothbrush. We travel at different times and it's difficult to share a single base and single toothbrush, even though you can change the head on it. Could you make an option that comes with two charge spots as well as brushes that would be less costly than purchasing two separate units? Also, the heads that come with the brush are the compact type. If you prefer the standard heads as we do, you will have to purchase them separately. Otherwise they have performed as advertised and have some very good features that we like. I have not tested the length of the charge yet, but will edit my review if it does not match what is advertised. They arrived two days after purchase as promised using my Amazon Prime account.
  74. I had this toothbrush for one year, and was loving it. But then, a few weeks ago, I accidentally dropped it in a sink full of water and it immediately shorted out. It won't turn on, charge, or anything. Why would you make an electric toothbrush that isn't completely waterproof???
  75. The sonic care flex plus gives mouth a super clean feeling, however the strong vibration of the brush does take getting use to. It stays charged for a very long time and cleans my teeth better than I ever could with a regular brush. I'm very happy with my purchase.

  78. We've been Sonicare fans for years and used several earlier versions of their brushes. This latest upgrade feels like a big step up. Not only does the new handle design eliminate that truly icky build-up under the replaceable brushes (gross!), but the brush sanitizing light (gimmick or not) at least makes you feel like you're being a little more safe, germ-wise. (And, hopefully, eliminates throwing away those expensive brush replacements every time you've got the sniffles.)<br /><br />I'm not sure how useful the variable speeds/setting are, but the total care cleaning setting definitely left my mouth feeling refreshed and throughly cleaned without taking too long to be doable on a daily basis. I'm not sure I'd say it's a dentist's clean feeling every day, but your teeth and mouth definitely feel far cleaner and more refreshed after a Sonicare brushing than using any regular brush.<br /><br />The downside, of course, is the Sonicare price tag (and ongoing replacement brush head costs), but, in the end, I feel it's worth it and don't think I'd ever go back to using just a regular toothbrush again after so long with a Sonicare.
  79. I love my new Sonic toothbrush. It was bought to replace an older Sonic that finally quit. I had to go several days with a regular toothbrush before my new toothbrush arrived. It felt like forever. I couldn't wait to get my new one and really feel like I had a clean mouth and teeth. It's great!
  80. I have owned each of the last 3 generations of Sonicare toothbrushes... this latest version is head and shoulders above the rest. I can't recall my original Sonicare toothbrush, I ended up not using it too much. The last toothbrush, the Sonicare Elite has the highly distasteful tendency to get mold/gunk inside the body of the brush no matter how much I cleaned it. That issue with the Elite version was a design failure in my mind. This version, the FlexCare plus, gets it right. The controls on the handle are easier than the previous versions and I am very very happy with how Sonicare has improved the design of the toothbrush head to avoid the issues that the Sonicare Elite had. I don't use the UV that much, its nice to have and the non-UV isn't that much cheaper right now. The nice thing about the UV is it creates a wider base which helps to stabilize the toothbrush from being knocked about. From a pure cleaning functionality perspective.... this is a great toothbrush, works very well. Best product out there in my mind.
  81. This is by far the best electric toothbrush I have tried that is currently on the market. The bristle's are still a little too hard and the vibrations are still too hard as well, so can I recommend this, not really. I still say a soft or ultrasoft bristled brush is the best for MOST people. I do like the UV, though I really don't know how well it works, and quite honestly, your mouth is already full of bacteria and if you are healthy, there should be a good balance and while it is a good marketing tool, I don't know how necessary it is. This will still rattle your teeth if the back of the brush touches them, so be careful, it's quite a jolt. You will still get toothpaste all over the place. Even at it's lightest setting it's just too much. Also, something to note is that the amount of time you brush is very important and you cannot compensate with a harder bristled brush. You really do need 3 minutes to brush every area well....and you should be brushing softly. I would have given this 3.5 stars if it were possible. If you don't brush your teeth and you need to spend this much money in order to motivate yourself, then I guess it's a start. Keep in mind that (basically) gingivitis is initially caused by plaque accumulation and soft plaque can be removed by good hygiene (e.g. brushing AND flossing). Once the plaque hardens it needs to be scaled off and there isn't a brush in the world that will remove it (or if there is it shouldn't be in your mouth). If you have arthritis, etc., this is probably the only reasonable alternative. I wish they could tone it down a bit more, say 50% more. Lastly, keep in mind that you still have to floss (at least twice a day). :-)
  82. This is the most amazing toothbrush ever. As my daughter would say I love it so much! I also like the fact it has a sanitizer attached to sanitize me brush heads. Thanks Sonicare !!!
  83. Works great, holds a charge for many days. Love all the features. It programs you to clean your teeth longer. You need this, floss, a scraper for plaque, a mirror, and voila! you are your own hygienist.
  84. I have owned Sonicare products for many years but this one is exceptional. You can see the difference in the brightness of your teeth and feel how smooth your teeth are. I now have next to no tarter, my teeth are cleaner and whiter than ever, my gums are healthy and going to the dentist is now a snap. My first Sonicare lasted over 13 years and both my husband and me used it. We now use the Flexcare Plus and love it. I love that the head is smaller and can more easily get to the back teeth, I love how the toothbrush has a break-in period so that your gums and teeth get used to it, I like the different options available and the fact that it has a built in sterilizer and travel charger. The Sonicare has proven itself over and over for years. There is no product that compares to this.   91. My dental hygeine has benefited infinitely from the Sonicare line of toothbrushes. This is my third Sonicare brush and it replaces a first-generation [[ASIN:B0013TVEWA Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush]]. I'm finding the + model to be a worthy upgrade. Immediately noticeable was the more solid feel, better grip, and improved balance of the handle. The brush modes are labeled in plain English--Clean, Gum Care, Refresh, Sensitive, and Massage--rather than settings like Go Care and Max Care that I never understood on my earlier model. I brush my teeth frequently and I love the new Refresh mode for a quick 1-minute clean to supplement my full nighttime and morning, 2-minute Clean. The FlexCare+ has a subtler, but more effective, vibration than my earlier model. My previous model did not have the sanitizer. I typically think of things like UV sanitizers as unnecessary and gimmicky, but it at lease appears to be doing something. Who knows, it can't hurt. The hard case and additional small-size charger are nice additions for the traveller, though I wish the charger could somehow fit inside the case with my brush. All in all a worthy upgrade.

  95. I have been a Sonicare user for over 10 years. Our original version lasted over 5 years. 3 of the last 4 brushes have stopped working properly. The first stopped vibrating properly within 2 years and the other 2 brushes stopped just after the 2 year warranty ended. This is very dissapointing given how expensive these brushes are. Sonicare does a great job but the life span of handles is just not acceptable. Sonicare should extend their warranty period and acknowledge that there is a problem with a significant percentage of their brushes. You should buy Sonicare only if you are satisfied with it lasting 2 years.
  96. This model (HX6950) is currently the ultimate rechargeable toothbrush that dental offices seem to recommend (or at least have coupons for). I've noticed less plaque build-up and healthier gums ever since I started using the older model (HX6930) a few years ago. So the question is, if you already have a Philips Sonicare Flexcare, do you need this new model?<br /><br />UV SANITIZER<br />============<br />I love the comfort of knowing that the germs on my toothbrush have been killed off. The UV sanitizer does a quick and effective job of that. Just insert up to 2 toothbrush heads and press the button. Not all Sonicare toothbrushes have a UV sanitizer, so this would be the main reason for me to upgrade.<br /><br />From the Sonicare website, the UV bulb lasts about 1800 hours (about 2 years) and can be replaced from their webstore. The recommended frequency of using the UV sanitizer is once a day.<br /><br />DIFFERENCES with older HX6930 MODEL<br />===================================<br />I bought the older Sonicare Flexcare HX6930 from Amazon a few years ago. Since then, Philips has made some slight improvements. These improvements seem to be cosmetic only.<br /><br />I've noticed that the UV sanitizer door now magnetically closes.<br /><br />The names of the toothbrush modes are changed but seem to have the same functions as the earlier model.<br /><br />- Clean (The basic 2 minute clean)<br />- Sensitive (The adjustment for sensitive teeth)<br />- Massage (The gum massage mode)<br />- Refresh (The 1 minute clean. This is re-named from \\"Go Care\\")<br />- Gum Care (The 2 minute clean plus 1 minute gum cleaning. This is re-named from \\"Max Care\\")<br /><br />GRIPE<br />=======<br />I love this toothbrush, but my complaint about the mold build-up in the earlier model persists to this model. It's very easy for water to be trapped under the UV sanitizer door which leads to mold growing in there. You'll need to periodically remove the plastic caddy inside the sanitizer and clean it to prevent build-up.<br /><br />You'll also need to wipe off any water on the toothbrush before placing it back on the induction recharger. It rests flat on the charging area without any grooves to drain water. So trapped water *inside* the bottom of the toothbrush will give your toothbrush a really funky odor.<br /><br />EXTRAS<br />======<br />Includes a convenient travel case and travel charger. (If you give it a full charge, your toothbrush should last more than a week, so you may not need to pack the travel charger).<br /><br />TIP<br />====<br />Register your toothbrush via the registration card for $30 in coupons from Philips to use on Sonicare replacement heads.acing it back on the induction recharger. It rests flat on the charging area without any grooves to drain water. So trapped water *inside* the bottom of the toothbrush will give your toothbrush a really funky odor. EXTRAS ====== Includes a convenient travel case and travel charger. (If you give it a full charge, your toothbrush should last more than a week, so you may not need to pack the travel charger). TIP ==== Register your toothbrush via the registration card for $30 in coupons from Philips to use on Sonicare replacement heads.

  100. This is a great toothbrush. I use it along with my wife, with separate brush heads, and the process is very manageable. I use the compact and she uses the regular brush head. Both seems to work very well. The brush has several settings depending on time you want to dedicate to the brushing, based on sensitivity of gums and also includes a gum massage mode. The battery charge is very solid, and for two people, using it everyday, it seems to last a long time. The UV sanitizer comes with this Kit, and while I can not vouch for the scientific benefits of such a devices, the blue light comes on every night, and it at least makes me feel more comfortable knowing I have less germs on my toothbrush. Look out, or search on the internet for a $15 coupon that is sometime available as a rebate from Sonicare. Enjoy this product, hopefully as much as I have.

  119. So far so good. I love this toothbrush. I don't think I'd go as far as saying I feel \\"dentist\\" clean after using this thing but it is exponentially better at removing plaque than a regular toothbrush. I discovered quite quickly that if you want your toothpaste to stay on your brush be sure to place the brush head inside your mouth before turning on the Flexcare+. So far I have used the Clean and Gum Modes and the quadpacer has does its job well. I think I prefer Gum Mode as I like the extra 15 second intervals (1 min total) at the end for targeting the insides of my molars. I have been using the UV sanitizer after each brushing and I assume it is doing its job. The intensity seems spot on and the 10 minute cycle seems about right. I've been digging for the actual clinical studies that Philips commissioned but I can't find anything other than a weak abstract on the Philips site. You would think if this UV thing of theirs worked as they claim they would give consumers access to the detailed results. I have not had any issues with this product yet. I hope it lasts at least throughout the 2 year warranty period since the cost was so high. The main thing that scares me is removing and replacing the brush heads after each use. All that pushing and pulling seems like it is destined to break something in the handle.

  122. this is my third Sonicare toothbrush, and the best. It definitely cleans teeth superbly - not only can i tell it, but the dental hygienist i go to says \\"Whatever you're doing to keep your teeth clean, keep it up\\". Before i started using the Sonicare, the dental hygienist used to have to do a lot of plaque scraping, but no more. The last Sonicare i used had a screw-on brush, and over time gunk built up under the screw-on cap. I was only aware of it when i changed the brush (every 3 months, as recommended by my dentist), but i didn't like the idea. This flexcare has a snap-on brush with no space beneath for anything foreign to build up. Even better, this unit has an ultraviolet light that kills germs and keeps the brush sanitary. (I have a UV light on both a hot tub and a koi pond, and you can see the difference they make in just a day). The battery stays charged for over a week of use when on trips, so no need to carry the charger. So - clean teeth and clean brush, no plaque, easy to use, and various special features (like the battery indicator). Well worth the money!
  123. Easy to clean and does not collect junk like the old model. Very satisfied with the upgrade!
  124. excellent product - i read all the mixed reviews about several versions of the Sonicare before finally deciding to purchase this one (FlexCare Plus). whatever problems there may have been with earlier iterations, i believe Philips has resolved. some definite pros:<br /><br />1) the design itself is impeccable and makes it easy to clean/maintain (that being said it is an extremely low-maintenance product anyway)<br />2) i purchased the one with the UV sanitizer which is great, but even if you don't go that route the individual brush heads come with caps as well, which could help you feel a little better about cleanliness if the unit stays out on the counter as opposed to in a drawer or medicine cabinet.<br />3) the gradual increase in pressure over the first 14 uses of the brush = brilliant!<br />4) multi-level settings for full/extended brushing or quick refreshers when you are headed out somewhere<br /><br />i've had this toothbrush for about 6 months now and so far it is living up to its potential and delivering on all the points referenced in the product description (not sure about the longevity of the battery - i haven't had any need to travel since buying mine and i keep it stored on the base).<br /><br />hope this information helps you in your purchase decision!<br /><br />**UPDATE: 29 November 2011 - It has now been well over a year since i first posted the above review about this toothbrush. it is still in great working condition, and my husband now has his own brush head attachment so he can steal, er...i mean BORROW it to use for himself. So far so good; a sound investment!<br /><br />**UPDATE: 28 April 2013 - i am about to order this same product for my mother, and thought i would update again to say this toothbrush is still going strong. i've also traveled with it a couple of times now, and it has easily held its charge for an extended weekend trip (so, i can vouch for about 3 days with no worries!).
  125. I would actually give it a 4.5 out of 5 stars but figured I'd round to 5. There's no need to go on about what I like about this toothbrush since many other reviewers go into fine details about what there is to like about it. And I'd have to say just about everything. I do love this Sonicare toothbrush very much in the 4 months that I've been using it. But the one detail or flaw that I find to be bothersome is the silver button to scroll through the different brushing modes. I always brush in the \\"Clean\\" mode of the five modes and since this button is in the mid area of where your fingers wrap around the handle to hold it what happens is in the process of going to put my toothpaste on and then pressing the bright green circular ON button to start brushing is 4 out of 5 times it ends up being on a different mode. And the reason for this is that while handling the brush prior to brushing you don't realize your are indirectly pressing that silver button once or twice or more, so when you finally come to press the ON button it's been set to a different mode than when you last brushed. You then have to press the green button OFF, press the silver button however many times to get back to the one you want and then press turn it back on. What I would say is a minor inconvenience and this happens very often to me.<br /><br />To resolve this problem is fairly simple, which is to check the mode your on (by pressing the silver button) right before you press the ON button to start brushing. But by doing this sometimes you have to scroll through the modes (pressing it several times) to get to the mode you previously had it on -- in my case, the 'Clean' mode. And I usually forget to check this prior to brushing. That's the only negative thing I have to say about this fine, well-made toothbrush. Certainly not a reason not to get it.

  133. The littlest you need to know: this is a great electric toothbrush, buy it!<br /><br />The Sonicare Flexcare Plus is my daily indulgence. With all the modes possible, you are free to choose one variation to suit your mood at use time. From the more intensive and longer \\"Clean\\" to the \\"Refresh\\" mode, there's something here for even the most rushed of users.<br /><br />The charge lasts for an inordinately long time--for me, about a week's worth of morning-only brushings without recharging. With a replaceable head, identifiable with colored bands, different people can use the same base, very cool. Although the cost of replacement heads makes a cheapskate like me less eager to switch out, the heads are very long-lasting nevertheless making it a good quality.<br /><br />If you're a regular viewer of the Mythbusters show, you'll no doubt have seen the episode dealing with toothbrush hygiene and how ridiculously difficult it is to keep germs, especially of the fecal kind, off the brush head. Well, the Flexcare plus comes with an Ultraviolet brush head sanitizer. I don't know how effective it truly is--you'd need a microbiologist on hand for that--it gives you a good feeling nevertheless to know you're brushing with a sanitized brush!<br /><br />With the included hard case and a travel charger, this toothbrush is portable and ready to go wherever you go. There really isn't anything I would disparage about the Flexcare Plus. It makes brushing easier and more efficient, all without too much thought. What's not to like?<br /><br />Recommended and five stars!

  167. Years ago, I purchased the original SoniCare. I used that SoniCare for years, without problems, until the battery stopped. I loved the 'sonic' vibration, and I had very few dental problems. When I shopped to replace my toothbrush system, I decided to try the Oral B 'rotating' system. I used the Oral B system for almost 1 year and was very unhappy... I had more dental problems, and my teeth never felt clean... so I shopped Amazon to find the BEST (and most expensive) SoniCare currently being sold. I decided to buy the SoniCare Flexcare Plus 'sonic' system... I was sold on the compact size of the Flexcare Plus, and I was especially pleased with the antimicrobial light that magically dissipated germs.<br /><br />Well, I have had the Flexcare Plus for about 13 months. I never write reviews, but I felt it was important enough.... so here I sit. To me, my experience is so important I must let others know, so you can make the right decision. Here is what I experienced over the last 13 months.....<br /><br />The SoniCare Flexcare Plus system is smaller than the first SoniCare I purchase years ago. I mention this because the sonic vibration created by the new style so much less than the sonic vibration produced by my original SoniCare. I am not an engineer, but my guess is the smaller sized handled reduced the space needed for the maximum movement of the metal shaft. Yes, you may get the same, or even more vibrations per second... but I am convinced that the overall sonic range was less on the new design. Additionally, my visits to the dentist show multiple new problems, serious problems such as deep root and deep gum problems. Since I've been using the new Flexcare design, I have also needed two new crowns... not because the crowns were old or failing, but because bacteria had entered underneath and into the nerves.<br /><br />I've also had other problems with the new Flexcare system. First, I have had problems with the antibacterial 'light'. The light works about 50% of the time. At one point, I thought the bulb needed replacement, but upon further fideting, I discovered the bulb would come on when I tapped the unit. The second, bigger problem is the vibrating shaft has loosened. The 'sonic vibration' has slowly reduced over time due to the loose shaft... finally, last week, the shaft stopped vibrating completely.<br /><br />Ok... The unit has a 2-year warranty. I will see how great the Customer Service team responds to my service call. I am a consumer that detests having to call, package, ship and wait for any repair. I prefer to pay top dollar and have NO problems. Well, the SoniCare Flexcare Plus system was the most EXPENSIVE system available (around $170.00 dollars).... I wanted top quality, but learned that the older model, which I could have purchased much, cheaper, would have performed better and most likely still be working. IN ADDITION, what about the $2,900 in dental bills I've now accumulated? Do you think SoniCare will help pay these bills?<br /><br />Summary - If you buy an electric toothbrush, I highly suggest the original SoniCare product. It has a hefty handle, but performs so much better. In addition, you will save mega-bucks on the original system purchase, and the replacement brushes are cheaper than the new 'tiny' heads. I learned a valuable lesson... sometimes newer is NOT better. In addition, more gadgets equate to potential repair problems. Keep it simple, save money and purchase the Original SoniCare or Original Oral-B systems!<br /><br />I'll update after I discuss my problems with Customer Care... sorry, I need to run, I have a dental appointment!t one point, I thought the bulb needed replacement, but upon further fideting, I discovered the bulb would come on when I tapped the unit. The second, bigger problem is the vibrating shaft has loosened. The 'sonic vibration' has slowly reduced over time due to the loose shaft... finally, last week, the shaft stopped vibrating completely. Ok... The unit has a 2-year warranty. I will see how great the Customer Service team responds to my service call. I am a consumer that detests having to call, package, ship and wait for any repair. I prefer to pay top dollar and have NO problems. Well, the SoniCare Flexcare Plus system was the most EXPENSIVE system available (around $170.00 dollars).... I wanted top quality, but learned that the older model, which I could have purchased much, cheaper, would have performed better and most likely still be working. IN ADDITION, what about the $2,900 in dental bills I've now accumulated? Do you think SoniCare will help pay these bills? Summary - If you buy an electric toothbrush, I highly suggest the original SoniCare product. It has a hefty handle, but performs so much better. In addition, you will save mega-bucks on the original system purchase, and the replacement brushes are cheaper than the new 'tiny' heads. I learned a valuable lesson... sometimes newer is NOT better. In addition, more gadgets equate to potential repair problems. Keep it simple, save money and purchase the Original SoniCare or Original Oral-B systems! I'll update after I discuss my problems with Customer Care... sorry, I need to run, I have a dental appointment!

  187. I have used the original Sonicare toothbrush for about 6 years until I noticed my dentist had this model sitting in his office at my last check up so I was intrigued. Of course, the original will still do the trick but Phillips seems to have figured out all of the flaws of their original design and made the sonic toothbrush twice as good, including a sleeker, smaller design. The biggest complaint I had of the original was the mold that would build up on the inside of the handle unless you cleaned it meticulously on a regular basis. (I know, gross but even if you replace your brush head every 3 months like recommended it's easy to forget to clean out the moisture inside which can build up into mold). That problem is solved with a snap-in brush head instead of the hollow screw on replacement head. What got me excited about this toothbrush was the UV light which plugs right in like normal and next to it, you can charge the toothbrush base. This UV light sanitizes the brush in as little as 10 minutes and it's not large and clunky. The motor on this model is also much quieter compared to the original which is a plus. Overall, I have had better check ups at the dentist over the past few years because of the Sonicare toothbrush and while my dentist will agree that you don't need the fancy UV light to have healthier gums, this is a definite upgrade that was well worth the investment on my part. I love the bonus of a built-in sanitizer on my toothbrush! If you're just investing in a sonic toothbrush, this is well worth the money in my opinion.
  188. This is my 3rd Sonicare toothbrush. They just keep getting better. This new FlexCare is more complex to operate but does a superior job. Recommended by my dental technician.
  189. I have two of this brush. Both can't hold longer than 8months. I got a replacement from Philips but its broken now as well. Can I get another replacement?
  190. This is a great electric toothbrush which has numerous modes. As I am not a man of many words, I will say this: \\"It is by far the best toothbrush I have ever owned.\\"
  191. I was disappointed with the Soniccare. I used a Oral-B cleaner for the last six years. After my son saying get a new toothbrusher cleaner. I bought this Soniccare toothbrush. My teeth didn't feel clean. The Soniccare hurt my gums that i had to see the dentist for the pain. Needless to say, I went back to my Oral-B that has served me well for the last six years.

Electric kettle. Died. Toothbrush. Died. At least within warranty.
  194. At the frequent nagging of my dentist, I finally sprang for this, and bought it at the dentist's office for a slight discount. The sensation was off-putting at first, but I got used to it after a few days. It does throw off the toothpaste, so one must smear it on one's teeth before turning the brush on. It seems to clean fairly well, and my gums do feel healthier, if nothing more. I'm not sure about whitening claims. Does the sanitizer work? Well, we have no way to tell, really. You place the brush inside the case and it glows like uranium. For $30, the replacement brushes are the big catch here, kind of the same rip off as overpriced ink for computer printers. Naturally, Phillips wants us to buy new ones every three months, but I suspect that could be stretched to six months. Still, if you are making the big switch to electric, you have no choice but to buy them periodically. I'm sure their actual cost is pennies. If you care to drop over $100 on a toothbrush, this appears to have the endorsement of many dentists.

All I know is that this one is great because it doesn't vibrate so much that it hurts or makes my head feel like it's full of bees, but it really gets my teeth clean. The massage setting soothes my gums, which don't like being brushed, and that two minute timer is a Godsend (I am five, apparently, and I need to be reminded how long to brush). And it's really nice to have the blue light aspect, because bacteria is my No 1 enemy. My dentist actually noticed a difference after only a week of using this. When this one finally dies someday I will definitely get another.

  212. I bought this toothbrush last April after my last Sonicare toothbrush finally died after almost ten years of use. Unfortunately, this new one was much more short-lived. Especially liked that I could take it with me traveling for short trips without having to bring a charger. However, now, suddenly, the vibrations are so slowed and weak that I might as well be using a manual toothbrush. I called Philips Sonicare and they are sending me a new toothbrush free of charge. Based on some other reviews, I am concerned this problem is not an isolated case and I am hoping I won't have to replace it repeatedly. During the two year warranty period, this would be merely annoying but I would expect a toothbrush that costs this much to last well beyond the warranty period. If all is OK with the replacement brush after several years of use, I will update my rating to more stars. UPDATING this review. I have had to replace the handle five times since my original purchase. That's an average of over once per year. It was under warranty the first two times only. Finally giving up and buying an Oral B. Not only is replacing the handle expensive, it is increasingly hard to find. Philips Sonicare will not sell a replacement handle; they reserve them for warranty replacements. Too bad, because while it works, it is great.

I have not had to use it but I see no problems with it as far as cleaning it or it opening during travel. My only complaint which is a bit frustrating is the blue bristles, after three uses, starting fading. Now I know it says you replace the brush heads every three months but it also says that the blue bristles are a marker for when the heads should be changed. By the end of one month the blue was all the way down. The bristles seem fine and still firm enough to continue but I feel its a bit misleading. Whatever the case may be I will be sticking to changing the heads every 3 months even if the blue markers fade early. New Flexcares are the way to go in my opinion. The look and feel of this tooth brush is very high tech and sleek. In comparing the Elite model with the Flexcare plus I have noticed a tremendous amount of improvements. The first is the Procare brush heads that come with this toothbrush. They are slightly more course (which I like) than the original brush heads that I bought for my Elite. They also have a blue strip on them which diminishes in time to signal when you need to replace the brush head. It just feels like my teeth are cleaner than when I used the Elite. Also the 5 modes of cleaning you can choose from compared to only one with my Elite. The quadpacer feature is pretty nice. It is basically a small and short beep every 30 seconds to signal you when you should switch brushing from one quadrant of your teeth to another. And the last thing that leapt out at me was the UV sanitizer built in to the charger. After 5 years with one model, I was growing paranoid about the cleanliness even though you change up brush heads. Some added accessories come in very handy if you travel a lot. A miniature travel case with an extra brush head and a miniature charger come with this purchase. I highly recommend this item to anybody.

  229. BACKGROUND: I have been using the [[ASIN:B0013TVEWA Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush]] (see my previous review for a detailed write up) for about a year and a half before getting the FlexCare Plus with the UV Sanitizer. For this review, I will highlight the differences between the two models as well as comment on the UV Sanitizer, and I will conclude with an overall recommendation between the two.<br /><br />SETUP: Much like previous units, this is a breeze. Simply plug in the base sanitizer/charging unit combo and place the base handle on the peg to begin charging. The instructions recommend charging 24 hours prior to the first use, but I doubt this is necessary given that the brush will only be used minutes a day and likely be able to charge 23 hours minimum every day that you use it.<br /><br />For multiple users, Philips again includes the standard colored rings to distinguish one brush head from another. For this unit, Philips includes both a standard and a compact brush head. These compare well with manual toothbrushes so it's a matter of preference. However, some will find it nice to try out both sizes before ordering new brush heads.<br /><br />USAGE: The basic operation of the FlexCare Plus is the same as the previous model. It uses the same Quadpacer signal in thirty second intervals over two minutes in the \\"Clean\\" mode. It seemed to me that this unit pulses a little faster, yet it is also quieter while running. You can still discern the signal when it is time to change \\"zones\\" on your teeth.<br /><br />Philips did a nice job of simplifying the mode selection over the previous FlexCare model. There are five modes to choose from: Clean, Gum Care, Refresh, Sensitive, and Massage. This is much more user friendly than the previous model's Clean, Sensitive, and Massage modes paired with the separate routines of Go Care and Max Care. I stick to the Clean mode for the most part, but the Refresh is a nice one minute version of Clean if you doing a simple between brushing touch up.<br /><br />As for the UV Sanitizer, I am not able to do a scientific test of whether or not it provides added benefit. I did some research that suggests that UV Sanitizers are effective, but that is taking someone else's word for it. What I can say is that it does operate as the instructions indicate. Once you remove the brush head and insert it into the peg stand and close the door, pressing the power button once starts a 10 minute cycle that shuts off automatically. The blue light is fairly bright and much larger than the green battery indicator on the main brushing unit. If you use this right before bed, you will probably want to close your bathroom door to avoid having the nice blue glow in your bedroom. I did find that after the 10 minute cycle was complete, the brush head was dry as far as I could tell. This is important since the sanitizer becomes a closed container, and excess water could cause mold/mildew. In the end I can't offer any negatives on the UV Sanitizer which is good because (as of this writing) the only FlexCare Plus model you can by is this one. There is currently no standalone model.<br /><br />Battery life is rated for 42 two minute brushings, but I don't think most people will ever put this to the test. An individual would have to be away from home for three solid weeks and not take their travel charger to drain the battery.<br /><br />ACCESSORIES: One of the things I criticized on my older FlexCare brush was the soft travel case. Philips stepped up on the FlexCare Plus and added a hard plastic case that holds the base unit and two brush heads. They also include a travel charger, which is nice, but you would only need this for an extended trip away from home with the increased battery life.<br /><br />DRAWBACKS: There really aren't any. Some may find the price steep, but you do get what you pay for. Perhaps offering a unit without the UV Sanitizer could lower the pricesome, but I wouldn't expect a large difference.<br /><br />CONCLUSION: Philips has done what all manufacturers should strive to do in the next generation of a product. They kept what worked and made improvements in the shortcomings of the prior version. After having used a Sonicare FlexCare brush for over a year and a half, I highly recommend this model to anyone looking for a new power toothbrush. If you have the older FlexCare model, I would wait until it is time to replace your old one before upgrading as the differences, while improvements, are not substantial.some, but I wouldn't expect a large difference.<br /><br />CONCLUSION: Philips has done what all manufacturers should strive to do in the next generation of a product. They kept what worked and made improvements in the shortcomings of the prior version. After having used a Sonicare FlexCare brush for over a year and a half, I highly recommend this model to anyone looking for a new power toothbrush. If you have the older FlexCare model, I would wait until it is time to replace your old one before upgrading as the differences, while improvements, are not substantial.
  230. I've been using this toothbrush for about a week and am amazed at the difference between this and when I used a regular toothbrush! I always considered myself someone with pretty good oral hygiene - brushed (with a regular toothbrush) twice a day, floss every other day. But since using this toothbrush, my teeth feel so much cleaner, even at the end of the day right before I'm going to brush again. My favorite aspects: - the UV tootbrush head cleaner - kills 99% of bacteria and is really quick - the fact that the cleaning is divided into 4 parts, 30 seconds each. It makes sure you brush for the full two minutes and get every part of your teeth. - the travel charger that comes with it - the fact that I know my gums are getting a great workout - it even has a setting called \\"gum care\\" The best thing about it is that though it gives you a great clean, it doesn't hurt or scratch your gums. The bristles are soft and the toothbrush isn't hard on your mouth. I definitely recommend this toothbrush, you and your dentist will be much happier!
  231. I've had the toothbrush for about a month and I love it - my teeth have never felt so clean! However, if I were to purchase again, I would choose the Sonicare Healthywhite for half the price or buy 2 of those instead of 1 of these. You basically pay alot of money for 2 things: UV disinfection and modes. I never used UV on my old toothbrush, and I've survived for 40+ years - I just make sure to rinse it well, and sometimes wash it with soap. But it's the \\"modes\\" that really seem like a waste of money - - they just make the brush run for more or less amount of time, rather than the standard 2 minutes. Big whoop. You can easily brush for half as long, or 50% longer . . . the thing beeps every 30 seconds . . . pretty basic. It takes more effort to switch between modes than to simply take the darn thing out of your mouth halfway through the cleaning cycle. WTF? I just don't get it. Save your money and buy the more basic model - unless you simply have to have the UV disinfection.
