  234. The Pro Results toothbrush is our 3rd Sonicare, and the best yet. I say this for two reasons, 1.) The heads do not collect toothpaste, gunk, etc in the bottom like the cheaper models can. This has do with the way the head attaches, instead of screwing on with a threaded skirt, they push onto a small peg. Very easy, very clean. Plus the UV head cleaner is a nice bonus 2.) The ability to select different brushing programs for quick touch-ups, normal brushing, or longer brushing is something I have been using more and more. Definitely worth spending the extra money to get the best model Sonicare offers.
  235. After my wife and I each had a recent trip to the dentist, where the previous version to this model of electric toothbrush was demonstrated and recommended by the hygienist, I started shopping around to find exactly what I was looking for. It quickly boiled down to a choice between this one and the comparable Oral-B model and my choice was made due to aesthetics and features; the two products seem to function pretty much same but Philips has a sleeker product with more possible options in the different packages they sell (and I was happy that my dentist gave me a $[...] mail-in rebate to sweeten the deal).<br /><br />Does it work? YOU BET! It's no joke when people tell you that you notice the difference after the first use. My mouth is left with a \\"squeeky clean\\" feeling and it hasn't changed during the few months I've been using this. The UV sanitizer was a major selling feature because my wife and I can each store our separate brush heads in the sealed unit away from the circulating air (remember that this sits on the counter top in the same bathroom where the toilet flushes!) and germs are killed with the UV light after a single push of a button. It comes with a travel case and the handle is supposed to work for 2 weeks between charges--I don't put it back on the charger everyday, only about once a week and it's always ready to go!<br /><br />Bottom line: it's a hefty sum to pay up front, but I expect my next cleaning at the dentist to last no-time. This is a terrific product with great features and I would definitely recommend this purchase to anyone who cares about their oral hygiene!

  239. I've switched back and forth between Sonicare and Oral-B over the years. I like the fact that Sonicare is now using lithium-ion batteries, and that they offer a compact head. They seem to do a better job cleaning my teeth, which is probably why my dentist recommends them. Overall, this is the best toothbrush I've ever used. I prefer this Flexcare Plus model because: - The battery lasts twice as long as Flexcare models - You can turn it on or off with just one press of the power button (the HealthyWhite models use the same button for power and mode changes) - It doesn't change brushing mode if I accidentally press the mode button while brushing my teeth, the way the Flexcare does - It comes with a decent hard travel case, where the Flexcare comes with a minimal soft case - The mode display is invisible when it's off, which looks nice I don't think the UV sanitizer is needed or desirable, so I don't use it. This model comes with a separate travel charger, but unlike the Flexcare, it doesn't have a cord wrap.
  240. Yes, get this one cause it solved the spit-drip-down-into-the-mechanism issue. This one works good like the others but will last longer cause spit/water won't get inside it like the other models. Dave Powers
  241. This arrived quickly and works great even after more than six months of use. Even after the very first use, your teeth feel so much cleaner. After using it for awhile, when you go back to using a regular toothbrush you will notice how different it feels, too.   245. First of all its a great brush! My handle stopped working about 8 months after I bought it. They are sending me a new handle and a prepaid box to sent my old one back, for free! Thanks Phillips Sonicare. Would purchase again if it breaks after my warranty expires in another year awesome customer service!
  246. Normally I don't write reviews of products I purchase (probably out of indifference) but in this instance, I feel compelled to state my experiences with a woeful dental product. Sonicare is touted to be the King of Brushes, but its anything but. I have had two SonicCare toothbrushes - in a bit of irony, one was given to me by a friend who was a dentist - and both broke down within a year. Whats more is that to repair these, they were going to charge me as much as it would have been to purchase a new one! (I had gone back to the store after the warranty period so I had to resort to asking about out-of-pocket costs). Whats more is that if you leave them standing near or on water, the rubber material grows mildew very quickly. Word to the wise, stay away from Sonicare brushes.

This toothbrush was recommended to me by my Dental Hygienist. She showed me the power the Sonicare has and stated it would really help me with the inflammation of my gums. I researched for several months as I still wasn't sure it was worth over $100. I decided to buy a much cheaper rechargable electric toothbrush first to see if I liked it. I noticed immediately that the other toothbrush wasn't as powerful as the Sonicare model the hygienist showed me. I then decided it was time to invest in this brush. I have to say, it's definitely worth every penny. My mouth feels so clean, just like after a cleaning at the dentist. I love the 'Gum Care' mode on this model. The travel case is really nice because I can pack this thing up, throw it in my bad, and not worry about it turning on or getting damaged while traveling. The battery life is also a lot better than older models (mine was really old so I guess that is to be expected). Overall I highly recommend the purchase for anyone who wants to take really good care of your teeth.

  269. You can get a Sonicare for much less than this. So why buy this one?<br /><br />I have some problems with my gums. The original Sonicare helped greatly with that. But this model even comes with a \\"gums\\" setting that gives you some extra time with gentle brushing to work on them.<br /><br />My old Sonicare was a pain to keep clean. This one has its own sanitizer/autoclave for the brush so I can stop worrying about what might be growing in there.<br /><br />This Sonicare comes with a nifty travel kit--a holder for the base and both brushes, and a separate, smaller \\"travel charger\\" (without the sanitizer unit). Nice feature, if you travel even occasionally.<br /><br />For me, that made it worth the extra money. And if those features matter to you, I am sure you will agree. But if not, choose the unit that meets your needs. They are all great.

  276. I bought this model to replace my Sonicare Elite that had started to stop working after 3+ years. I was excited to receive this model which is supposed to be the latest and greatest. However, I was very disappointed to find out that unlike the Elite, handle on the FlexCare is not dishwasher safe. You replace the brush heads every few months but the handle to supposed to last for years. If you're going to be touching something every day for years and putting it in or near your mouth, you want to know that it will stay clean. Running something through the dishwasher is one of the best ways to make sure that it's clean. Functionally, I'm happy with the new design. The new brush heads are less likely to accumulate grim. Still, I worry about how clean the handle it self will be a year from now since I won't be able to put it in the dishwasher to clean it. I'm giving it 4 stars because it's still one of the best tooth brushes that I've ever used and it has some advantages over the previous model. However, I hate it when the new and supposedly improved model drops important features and I consider a dishwasher safe handle to be a very important feature. (I would have given 5 stars if they had kept this feature.)
  277. Great product. Lasted about a year before the power weakened

  292. (I dont think my last one had that.)Personally I never use more than one or two settings, and I can tell when I need to change my bristles, and well good looks never hurt!<br /><br />The hard case is easily the only useful improvement (for me). And its a sorta of a bittersweet improvement. These toothbrushes are fragile around the neck. One drop onto hard tile, too much pressure applied the wrong way in your luggage and bam. I've lost two, one in each of those ways, but I keep replacing them, so take that for whatever its worth. Also I cant figure out how to fit the charger into the hard case but there must be a way. For dental cleaning without fuss<br />Buy this handy FlexCare +<br />Brush 2 minutes, twice a day<br />To keep those pesky germs at bay<br />It'll take no longer than the time<br />It took to write this little rhyme<br />So, make yourself a pledge this year<br />To brush your teeth with Sonicare<br /><br />Philips has for some time established itself as the leader in toothbrush technology, to the extent that dentists recommend it by name.<br /><br />This brush is no exception, with all the standard features of other models, but in a sleek new design that cuts down on some of the flashy lights, but not on the features.<br /><br />Pros:<br /><br />1. 5 brushing modes - clean, gum care, refresh, sensitive and massage.<br />2. Easy start feature for newbies to gradually introduce the Sonicare experience (can be deactivated if not needed)<br />3. Quadpacer timer to alert you when it's time to change from top teeth to bottom teeth, and from inside to outside areas.<br />4. Helpful little details like color-coded rings for multiple users, cord wraps to eliminate cord snarls, travel charger and travel case, 2 sizes of brushing head and an intelligible instruction manual.<br />5.   307. It worked great when I first got it. My teeth never felt cleaner. The UV light didn't last that long though, only about 4 months. The next time it broke, I just missed the stand and it fell onto the shelf right next to the charger. That was enough to break that piece again. Figured it was probably going to be done for good, I opted this time to just buy a whole new one. Of course, that one has died as well. I normally wouldn't dock any stars for my own clumsiness, but this is a piece of equipment that is used multiple times daily, and is subject to wet and slippery conditions. I know I'm not the only person in the world to drop their toothbrush. It just sucks when it costs $30+ every time you do to get it fixed.
  308. Best toothbrush I've ever had. Includes travel case and charger which is handy. I can already notice an improvement in my teeth compared to my older oral-b.
  309. Love this toothbrush!! Great price and great service!! I bought my husband one too!! Very easy to use and made very well.
  310. great item. my fiance and i both use it daily. works best in the shower as it continues to vibrate and will cause a bit of toothpaste splatter.
  311. The toothbrush came sooner than I expected and was fully charged! I love this toothbrush so far and haven't had any issues a month in.
  312. Does not clean between teeth. Waste of money. Oral B is much cheaper and does a better job. Even Gum message is useless. Will try to send it back!!
  313. This toothbrush is absolutely awesome. It's well worth the money... the price was the lowest I found anywhere. By it for yourself and/or your family. Everyone deserves one of these.
  314. You only thought you had brushed your teeth clean until you use a Phillips Sonicare Plus. It feels like you just had your teeth polished by your dentist. It takes a few uses to get use to how it works but I guess that is why it has the 14 uses building up to full power. Unlike other power brushes this one will last at least 5 days without being recharged. My only suggestion would be to make the pause between cycles more distinct; if you are not paying attention you can miss the change. My son also has one and after 2 months of use the stains from smoking are gone. Great investment. Cleaner, healthier teeth and gums plus you use a lot less toothpaste. It is expensive for a toothbrush but well worth the price.
  315. My dentist recommended this product due to my sensitivity and receding gums. I must brush my teeth too hard, so this helps me not do that. My teeth also feel nice and clean when I'm done and I can feel the pieces of food dislodging themselves as the brush \\"shakes\\" them loose. I love the ultraviolet cleaner because it makes me feel like I'm not putting any bacteria back in my mouth, especially after I've been sick or had a cold. I also love the fact that the brush gives you a signal when it's time to switch to the next section. This helps me not spend to little or too much time on any one area and keeps me focused when I'm in a rush.
  316. I have been using the Sonicare Flexcare+, along with a new Sonicare Airfloss for about two weeks now. The combination seems to be working great. I had gotten a bit lazy with brushing and flossing, and I started to notice some significant gum problems. Using the two Sonicare products has already caused noticeable improvement. I really don't know if the Sonicare Airfloss and a regular brush would have done the same thing, but I will say that this is a lot more pleasant. Because it is almost fun, I tend to brush and floss at least once every day. HOWEVER, with that said, look around for a better price than Amazon.com. I am a person that buys from Amazon without checking other sources because I feel that Amazon's price is generally pretty competitive. Not so with the Sonicare products. Both of these products are available on-line with a 20% discount (shipping included), a total savings of around $46!! Update 12/9/11: I just changed my rating to one star. The Flexcare Plus is dead and I am about to contact Philips for a replacement. The Powerfloss has already been replaced, and the new unit works, but makes loud crunching sounds. I don't expect that it will last much longer. These products both work well on your teeth, but the build quality seems to be so low that they don't last long.

  325. Read through all the one-star reviews before you buy. So many people have had the same problem as me: their toothbrush dying after 2 years, just outside the warranty. Yeah, it works great, but is that the kind of investment you want to make, close to $100 a year on a toothbrush? Most people write reviews after the first few months of having a product. Much less come back to say the thing broke after two years. Reviews are inherently biased that way. My experience, like so many others, was that one night, about two years after I purchased this item, it started turning on and off by itself. By the morning the brush was no longer working. I contacted Philips about this, both online and via phone, and they refused to replace it. When I talked about this with a friend, she said the same thing happened to her. Then I looked up the reviews, and saw many people talking about the same or similar problems. For only two years of reliable use, this brush is not worth the investment.

  327. This is the best model in the Sonicare line. The UV sanitizer is cool, but probably useless. Sanitizers most likely do not help, but they can't be bad either. This toothbrush is different from the old style sonicares. A piece of metal sticks up into the head to move it. The old versions used magnets to vibrate the head. The heads are now cheaper though. The battery lasts for a long time. This also comes with a travel case and a smaller travel charger which does not have the sanitizer. This is useful for packing easily. The case protects the toothbrush nicely. I put it in my luggage and the toothbrush arrived perfectly in the case. It has many different modes such as a gum care mode which is the standard brushing with a one minute period of gentle gum care massage. There is also a quick 30 sec mode and 1 minute mode. The feel of the toothbrush is comfortable and the brush does a great job cleaning teeth.

  333. This product comes with a traveling kit, a cleaning solution, and a pacing solution. The pacer allows you to have reproducible clean teeth. A standard cleaning session consists of 30 seconds on your front top teeth, 30 seconds on front behind teeth, 30 seconds of front bottom teeth, 30 seconds of bottom behind teeth. You are notified by a stop of small pause in vibration to tell you to move on to the next area. The vibrations are very strong which allow for a superior cleaning session. There are of course other specialized cleaning including with the brush such as gum care, message, and sensitive clean. The cleaning solution is a UV disinfect. You simply place the brush head into the cleaning unit, hit the clean button and it will automatically shutoff when complete. You are able to clean 2 brushes at a time. This addition adds peace of mind for germaphobes. I have yet to use the traveling kit, but looking at it, it's a hard plastic shell that can hold your tooth brush as well as a travel charger. Overall this is one of my favorite purchases and get excited to clean my teeth.
  334. I just got this toothbrush yesterday from my dentist. The first time I used it, it tickled a lot but I wasn't sure exactly how to use it. My dentist told me not to brush and let the brush do it's job.<br />It took a couple of times for me to get the hang of using it but I'm absolutely in love! My mouth feels so clean after brushing and I swear that since yesterday, my teeth are already noticeably whiter.<br /><br />I actually brushed my teeth with my old toothbrush as I normally would and then I brushed with the Sonicare brush afterwards. While I was spitting and rinsing after brushing the 2nd time with the Sonicare, I was surprised at how many food particles that my old brush missed! Eww!<br />This toothbrush actually shoots water/(spit, too?)/toothpaste in between your teeth instead of just spinning to clean the surface. This brush is gentle enough to where my gums don't bleed but are adequately cleaned. I adore the different settings and how the brush is on a timer and cuts off. It also gives warning beeps when you are brushing to notify you every 30 seconds (which can be deactivated). My teeth feel so clean that I now use the refresh mode after every meal as I can't stand the sensation of having little particles in my teeth.<br /><br />I haven't used the UV sanitizer yet but it sounds like it would be a good idea to disinfect at least weekly, if not several times a week. I love that the box came with an additional charger and also a travel case. The colored rings are a nice touch so you don't use someone else's brush head if you share with family members.
  335. Ok, this toothbrush is just amazing, works very well.<br />Let me start with the cons, as they are fewer:<br />Cons:<br />1- It's expensive<br />2- Additional brushes are quite expensive<br />3- the brush goes so fast, that any toothpaste just flies off the brush! Best thing I did was put some toothpaste on the brush, manually spread it around the teeth before turning on the device!<br />Once a layer of the paste is evenly distributed over the teeth, start using the brush.<br /><br />Pro's:<br />- Cleans very well<br />- Comes with a toothbrush case, with a bacteria killing UV bulb in it<br />- Does not hurt<br />- Looks cool!<br />- Works much better than any battery powered toothbrush I've ever used, and much much better than any manual brush!<br /><br />Other thoughts:<br /><br />To me personally, I think it's the future for everyone!<br />It's just indescribable how much better it is than my previous brushes.<br />First of all, it brushes so fast that you don't need to be spending long time brushing the teeth at all!<br />Second, it reaches between the teeth, something my circular (rotating brush) toothbrush had difficulty with.<br /><br />The brush gives off a tone of 500Hz, meaning it moves at about 500 brushes per second, and feels like a massage device, only vibrating much faster!<br />Using it tickles the gum a bit (comparable to when your arm or leg is asleep (due to lack of blood flow) comparable to the 'pins and needles' feeling, only much softer, with the difference that the feeling goes away as soon as one stops brushing the gum).<br /><br />After only 1 minute of brushing with this toothbrush, by teeth felt cleaner than 4 minutes cleaning with my battery powered toothbrush.<br /><br />I know that a new brush always works better in the beginning. But still, I was more surprised with this brush than any other I had before!<br /><br />Overall I believe it's a great improvement on personal hygiene, I'd recommend to anyone!<br />Especially young people in their 20's; as they still have a chance to save their teeth, and this tool is so much better than a regular brush!their 20's; as they still have a chance to save their teeth, and this tool is so much better than a regular brush!

  342. ***UPDATE 1 year later: The toothbrush itself is working fantastic, and there have definitely been positive changes - no more cavities, and the gum damage that was going on has been completely resolved. It can't fix my one tooth that is badly cracked and will probably need a root canal, unfortunately. But other than that, it's been a wonder worker. HOWEVER. Just today (almost exactly a year since I got it) the UV sanitizer stopped working, something that I recall seeing other reviewers comment about. The UV bulb should last 5 years, according to the Philips website. I just finished an online chat with one of their reps and they are sending out a new bulb to me for free. When I then asked what I should do if the new bulb does not work either at first they said that the warranty did not cover \\"parts and accessories\\", but when I pushed the issue a little the rep then told me that if the bulb does not work to contact them again and they would send a new sanitizer. So - we shall see what happens... I will try to remember to update here again with a resolution.<br />***************<br /><br />After years of struggling with horrid teeth problems and poor discipline in proper hygiene since it didn't seem to matter what I did anyway, I started going to a new dentist and hygienist. At my second visit they both suggested I should look into getting a Sonicare, any model but in particular one that had the gum care settings. They both told me that they each used one daily and had seen other patients improve drastically and that even though it seemed expensive, they really thought that it would improve my teeth/gums enough to basically pay for itself. I was skeptical, I mean, $100+ for a toothbrush? Not to mention the refill brushhead costs... But I figured after 30 years of pain and agony maybe I should bite the bullet and try it.<br /><br />Wow. The thing is all it says and more; I can't imagine not having it now. The many other reviews that say the same thing were what finallyconvinced me to take the leap, and so now let me add this review to theirs to help convince you!<br /><br />It certainly seems like it is a doing a far better job on my teeth than any toothbrush did before, none of that midday \\"film\\" that I used to get. It feels great both on my teeth and on my gums, I actually WANT to brush my teeth twice a day. And because I am better at brushing my teeth, it has been a lot easier to get disciplined about flossing and mouthwashing properly. All told, the difference between when I use it and when I don't is so drastic that I will take the time to brush my teeth even if I overslept and am late to work, no excuses.<br /><br />Smaller brushheads - I have a smaller mouth, even so the small brushhead seemed too small at first. But, once I got used to it I realized that even though it looks like a kid's brush it really is far better for my mouth than the \\"normal\\" large brushhead. Don't be afraid to try the small one too!<br /><br />Granted that I haven't been back to the dentist yet since getting it, I can't say for sure, but I will try to remember to come back and report if there is any positive changes.<br /><br />Just based on what I've experienced so far though, I wish I would have invested in one of these long ago. Go for it!

  347. This is my third Sonicare toothbrush, and so far, it's the highest quality Sonicare I've tried. I previously used the Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush, and like many reviewers, I had a problem with buildup at the bottom of the brush head. I've been using the FlexCare Plus two to three times daily for about a month now, and I haven't noticed any buildup so far. Just like the previous units, setup is simple. If you've already used a Sonicare, you can skip the ramp-up process and start the brush at full power. I'm not sure if the brush is actually more powerful than previous ones, or if the battery on my old one had slowly faded, but I thought the FlexCare Plus was more powerful off the bat. In addition, it seems to be quieter. Usage is the same as previous models--in the basic mode, it will give you a signal every 30 seconds so you can change \\"quads\\" in your mouth. The modes on the new FlexCare Plus are Clean, Gum Care, Refresh, Sensitive, and Massage. Personally, I prefer these modes to the previous model's Clean, Sensitive, Massage, Go Care, and Max Care. Switching between modes is easy and intuitive. I tend to use Clean twice a day, and Gum Care once. When you start the brush, it will assume you want to use the setting you last used. I also like having the UV Sanitizer on board. In the past, if I had a cold, I always felt the need to change my brush head so I didn't continue to give myself the same germs. Now, I just put the brush head in the UV Sanitizer after every use. It only takes about 10 minutes. The travel case is a big improvement over the previous case, but I do have one pet peeve--you can't fit the travel charger in the travel case. This isn't a big deal unless you'll be traveling for more than two weeks, but I do frequently go on extended trips, and I'd rather have a case that holds everything I need.
  348. This toothbrush is great, we had the older style, and crud used to build up inside the nadle and the brush heads. This one is so easy to clean, and the brush and sanitizer are both on the same base, only one outlet is needed now! Worth the money!

Somehow the suite was not included in my address, and UPS wouldn't deliver even though the name of my company is on the building and would be exceptionally easy to figure out. Now I have to wait for that to be shipped back to the warranty warehouse so they can send it back again. When I talked to customer service they said there was nothing they could do. No one attempted to reach me, from Philips or UPS, to get a suite number, although my phone number was correct. Maybe in another 2 weeks I can get back to brushing my teeth they way I like, at least until it breaks again. Update: It is now March 28, and I still have nothing but my broken toothbrush. The agent this time promised an expedited shipment will be going out soon. A month and a half is way too long. I had been unlikely to consider a competing brand based on my original high regard for the Sonicare line, but I would have to think very carefully about purchasing from them again after this extremely frustrating experience.

  356. I bought this Sonicare over the Oral-B at first based on the number of reviews on the [[ASIN:B000UK2W4C Philips Sonicare FlexCare Rechargeable Sonic Toothbrush with Sanitizer]], and thought this model is a step up so it has to be even better. That was not the case, and long story short, I now use an [[ASIN:B002HWS9GG Oral-B Professional Care SmartSeries 5000 Rechargeable Toothbrush]]. The Sonicare beats the Oral-B in most aspects except for the function in my opinion. It has a higher quality, more pleasing design than the Oral-B, which looks like a toy in comparison. All parts of the Sonicare are sealed and it can basically be submerged in water without having to worry about water getting into the handle, unlike the Oral-B. This isn't really a big deal, as I don't plan on using it while scuba diving, but it is a nice touch. The Sonicare also has a nicer display on the handle which actually shows the setting you select and the battery indicator is more modern, compared to the old-fashioned calculator type black LCD on the Oral-B. The Oral-B 5000 also lacks any display that shows which mode you have selected, but it isn't a big deal since you can easily tell by the different types of vibrations. The Sonicare has a lithium ion battery, and the Oral-B has a Ni-MH battery so the Sonicare wins in the battery department. The Sonicare can hold a charge for much longer than the Oral-B. The UV lamp was a big selling point for me at first, but after I bought it, I thought it was overkill, and probably not necessary as I have been doing fine for over a quarter of a century without a germicidal lamp for my toothbrushes. Most importantly, I felt that the Sonicare wasn't cleaning my teeth very well and I was just not satisfied with it. I even turned off the easy start mode and tried it at full power, and it still wasn't cleaning my teeth well enough. It also felt awkward. Perhaps I should have given it more time, but I just felt it wasn't working for me. The Oral-B's circular brush heads seem to work better in cleaning and I am happy with my Oral-B, even though it seems like Oral-B needs to scout some people from Sonicare's design team. The Oral-B handles and brush heads are cheaper and there are more varieties of brush heads as well so that is another plus for the Oral-B. I know this is supposed to be a review for the Sonicare, but I just wanted to be helpful to the people who are trying to decide between Sonicare and Oral-B like I did.
  357. First one broke within 2 days. Amazon sent a new one next-day. Nice of them. They replaced it with the HX6910/HX6160, which is now discontinued according to Philips. I went on vacation, and when I returned home, the UV sanitizer was no longer working. Correction. It would work once every 20-30 times I pressed the button. Contacted Amazon, and since it was past 30 days since my purchase, they referred me to Philips. I chatted with them for about an hour. They said, \\"This product is discontinued\\". I asked them how they were going to resolve my defective product. They are shipping me a new base unit. I like the toothbrush, and the sanitizer seems like a good idea. Now if only it would work. This has been very frustrating. I would avoid this model.
  358. I want to let people know about the poor company Philips is. I mailied the compay rebate paperwork on the 10th of Feburary, 2011 to get a $15 rebate from them. It was to take from 8-10 weeks to process and after that to get the rebate check. Their has been delay after delay on Philips part. 1. Was told I needed to wait until after the 10th week before Phillips would look into were my paperwork was. 2. They got my email address wrong, I missed a number of emails sent to the wrong address and can not get them sent back to me again with the right email address now. 3. Then the company has a six week issue were they process the checks and are just now telling me about this issue. Because their customer care people were not allowed to inform anyone they had the issue. The issue happened from the 23rd of March until the 9th of May 2011. Now they say they sent my rebate check out on the 9th of May. So, my main issue is not with Amazon; they did their job in getting me the Sonicare FlexCare Pus in two days.   359. My hygienist recommended that I get an electric toothbrush (not this one specifically), but I saw this product and read the reviews and found it much less expensive on Amazon than other places so I bought it. The toothbrush is awesome and it has really helped me brush better and I am brushing more often. However, the U/V sanitizer only worked the first time I used it and after that would not work at all, which was disappointing given the cost of this product. I did not want to give up the toothbrush by sending the product back to Amazon just because the U/V sanitizer didn't work (the charger still worked), so I simply called Philips customer support and they sent me out a replacement charger/sanitizer with prepaid shipping to send the original charger/sanitizer back to them. That was great customer service and the new U/V sanitizer has been working just fine. I love the toothbrush and the various settings, as well as the built in timers. I used to view brushing as more of a chore and typically brushed too hard and too long. This toothbrush takes all of the guesswork out of it and does an outstanding job.
  360. I did some research on the Sonicare web site to try and determine which model to buy. Wow, they have too many models! I ended up getting this model to get the toothbrush head UV cleaner, the hard travel case, and the gum cleaning mode, but I have to confess I have only used the gum cleaning mode once. All the gum cleaning mode does is add an additional minute at the end for gum cleaning. I do like the size of the handle, and the battery lasts many days, even if using 2-3 times per day. My only major complaint is how quickly the handle gets dirty with gunk. I need an old toothbrush to clean the Sonicare handle! This is not really the Sonicare's fault but is still gross. Another small complaint is that the head is a bit more difficult to remove than prior models I have owned where you screw them off. This one has to be pulled straight off, and I feel like I am going to break it. I am happy with this model and recommend it, even though it is a bit pricey.
  361. Love this toothbrush! My previous rechargable toothbrush from another company doesn't come close to this Sonicare. Everyday my teeth feel like I just had them professionally cleaned. You can store and clean the brush head in a small compartment next to the recharging handle. It comes with a travel power cord and a travel case for the toothbrush. Documentation says it actually holds a charge for 21 days but I haven't put it to the test yet. It may cost a bit more but I truly believe it will save a lot of money at the the dentist's.
  362. I've owned several toothbrushes in the past and none of them have cleaned my teeth like this Sonicare has. A couple of things to keep in mind: Make sure you use it for the recommended 2 minutes - don't cut that time short. Also, flossing and mouthwash should also continue to be used. However, if all three are done correctly, your dentist visits will be quick and easy. The only negative thing about this product -- the UV bulb sometimes won't come on, so I have to take it out and rotate it around in the device until it activates. This is a bit annoying. Other than this, great product!

  372. I'm a girl who grew up using technology from a very young age. While some people are technophobes, I am quite the opposite-- a gadget geek. So after years of finally debating whether or not it was worth it to make the switch from an old-fashioned toothbrush to an electric, I decided it was time to go for it-- and time to go for one of the best. After carefully comparing brands, costs, model features, and durability, I knew I wanted a Sonicare brush. Although they tend to be the most expensive brushes, they have longevity which stands out, much like the Kitchenaid of stand mixers. I decided to go for this model because it wasn't the highest model, yet it still had all the features I really needed. The gum care mode seemed great for me because I tended to bleed in my gums from brushing too hard. I would pretty much bleed every time I brushed my teeth-- that was what finally convinced me. Also, the UV cleaning part seems really awesome. I'm not sure if it actually works, but I put my brush head in for a cleaning after every use. At the very least, it's a placebo that makes me feel like it's becoming clean and I don't have to become some crazy germophobe. Beyond that, I was concerned about the fact that the brushes didn't rotate. But after reading all the reviews, I was convinced that this was the brush I had to have. I eagerly waited for my new gadget. I paid Amazon Prime for the overnight shipping, I was so excited. I tore the box open and plugged everything in. It should be noted that the toothbrush came ready-to-use with 2/3 bars of battery life. Brushing with this toothbrush feels like scrubbing your body after a long summer day. Incredibly refreshing, and you just don't realize how many unpleasant things are on your teeth until you use this toothbrush. I actually enjoy brushing my teeth because I love the feeling of them becoming clean. Yes, you can actually feel your teeth becoming cleaner while it works. I originally turned off the setting that allowed thebrush to beep every 30 seconds, indicating you should move onto another quarter of your mouth, I actually turned it back on, because I found if it wasn't on I wouldn't manage my tooth-brushing as accurately as I should have. Not only that, but unlike a normal tooth brush, you don't have to move your arm around. It's great for people with arthritis or carpal tunnel in your hands, because it has a wide handle that is easy to maneuver. It remembers your settings every time you use it. Apparently, it also has a setting that for the first few uses, it slowly increases its pressure so you can get accustomed to it-- a feature which was ingeniously awesome for people like me, switching from a normal toothbrush. The best part is that my gums haven't bled since I started using this, because now I don't have to apply lots of pressure to feel like my teeth are getting clean. I'm pretty sure my teeth are getting whiter. And I actually enjoy brushing my teeth. How can you beat that?
  373. This is the second Sonicare toothbrush I've bought. First one broke within 1-2 years. There's no way to repair it. So I bought a second one, broke down around the same time.<br /><br />The old Sonicare toothbrushes used to last much longer. Looks like the company is pumping up its profits by making them in a way that consistently breaks down shortly after the warranty expires.<br /><br />In sum, it works well, but replacing broken toothbrushes and buying new brush heads will run you around $200+ per year. Wish someone had told me this 4 years ago.
  374. I was impressed with this toothbrush upon my first use. I purchased after routine dental cleaning and everytime I use it I get that professional cleaning feel. It has included portable charger but it hold charges well so I did not need to charge it for week long trip.
  375. I have never purchased a power toothbrush until my dentist gave me a hard time during my last appointment. I read a ton of reviews on which one to purchase before settling on this brush. It's been a few months, and it has been great. Pros: -I LOVE the UV sterilization of the brushes -There's a 2 week \\"training\\" period when just start using the brush to get you adjusted -The battery life is great, I've kept it off the base for about a month and it's still charged -The pause system letting you know when to switch sections of your mouth -Instructions are very easy -5 different settings depending on what you want to do -Comes with multiple colored bands so you can share the wand and switch the heads Cons: -When you just get started it feels really odd and almost tickles. I've adjusted since, but the sensation was very awkward the first few times.
  376. This thing really humms. I can't feel the tarter on my teeth at the gumline anymore. I used the old brush the other day, boy what a waste of time that was. I especially like the 4 different cleaning times for each quadrant of your teeth. The unit stops for a microsecond and then you get on to another section 4 times and it cuts off. The infrared brush cleaner is also cool especially if you are a germ-a-fobic. They have models without that option and battery powered as well. Since the purchase was over 30 days ago, the Amazon vendor won't take it back. I now have to go directly to the manufacturer, box the damn thing up, and wait weeks for a replacement unit (assuming they honor the warranty). Nice.

  381. I'm gonna go ahead and throw this out there: I'm gross. I don't like brushing my teeth. I'm fine with it in the morning since nobody likes a stank-mouth and I do want to keep my teeth from rotting out of my head, but I've never really been a night brusher. Unless I've had something particularly offensive for dinner, I usually just fall into bed, plaque and all. This toothbrush has transformed me. I had a lot of cavities as a kid (as I'm sure you can imagine), and now that I'm an adult, those old fillings have started to go. As such, I recently had to have seven of them replaced (thankfully, no new cavities!). They also did a periodontal exam (which I hadn't had in a couple years), and I was shocked by how bad the results were. The dentist didn't freak out and tell me my gums were about to rot, but I did have much worse scores than I expected, considering I am a generally well-kept 25-year-old woman. I figured maybe it's time for something new in my routine. I am an engineer/total tech geek, so of course when I saw \\"UV chamber!\\" I immediately had to have this product. I mean, come on. Super cool. Plus it looks like a space toothbrush, and who doesn't love space? If sonic technology is good enough for Doctor Who, it's certainly good enough for me. Yeah, it's a pricey toothbrush, but so is getting fillings or being treated for gum disease. I've spent this much money on much more useless things. (Automatic electronic vacuum cleaner collecting dust in the corner, for example.) So, I ordered this toothbrush. I've used electric tootbrushes in the past. I can't recall which brand, but I know it wasn't a Sonicare. They worked better than a manual toothbrush, which is what I expected from this, but other than that I had no real expectations. After dutifully doing the 24-hour battery charge, I was very excited to brush my teeth. I turned on the Sonicare, and frankly, was immediately turned off. I thought my brain was going to rattle out of my head. Two lessons learned: This takes some getting used to, and a light touch is key. Holy clean mouth, Batman. I have never, never experienced this level of clean with a manual toothbrush. While I may not have LIKED brushing my teeth before, I would always be extremely thorough when I brushed. Too thorough, actually - my dentist saw some gum recession where I'd been brushing too hard. I can even get a really good clean back on my molars and wisdom teeth. Sure, they're coming out soon, but I'd still prefer they didn't rot before that happens. To attempt to not make an already-long review even longer, I am now obsessed with brushing my teeth. I've even been flossing at night and using mouthwash morning and night. I expect these other good habits to taper off as time goes on, but at least I'll still have my toothbrush. I actually wish I could brush my teeth MORE often - I can't get over how awesomely clean my teeth feel, and I want them to feel that way all the time. I have no doubt that my next dental exam will be very different. ---- The main takeaway: This is an excellent toothbrush. It's pricey, but you will never find a toothbrush that leaves your teeth feeling cleaner than this one, and personally I find it hard to put a price tag on excellent hygiene. And, if you are a gross person like me who usually doesn't like brushing, it will change your outlook. Particularly if you are the nerd variety and enjoy fun new gadgets, and being able to tell people that your new space toothbrush has a UV sanitation chamber.
  382. I received this Sonicare as a gift. I always wanted one but the price kept me away. I LOVE this so much that I have decided to purchase one for each of my children. IT is the best ever!!! My teeth felt so clean after brushing them and the next morning they still felt clean!   392. As of writing this review I have been using this toothbrush for 2 years. This is the second Philips sonic toothbrush I have owned. The first was an older type I used for about 2 years, but they discontinued it and no longer made the replacement heads so I bought this model. The first one did excellent and the several times I went to the dentist for a checkup after buying it I had practically no plaque on my teeth (and no cavities, but that was normal anyway). Usually I would have a little plaque in those hard to reach places, but now it was practically all gone. In fact, one time the dentist asked if I had just had my teeth clean recently, but I had not since my checkup about a year before. This toothbrush has had the same results as the previous one so I'm very happy with it. Also, the addition of the UV light to sterilize the heads is very nice. It also comes with a travel charger that is nice and compact so you don't have to stuff the entire base unit in your suitcase to go on vacation. That being said, I have used it for a week before without charge so short trips will not even require a recharge. Overall, I think this is a great toothbrush and I would recommend it, especially considering how important it is to take care of your teeth.
  393. The UV sanitizer bulb burns out. Finding a replacement is very difficult. I had to spend several hours before I was able to do so. Be wary of the product for this reason. Philips doesn't appear to care very much about customer service.
  394. I bought this toothbrush about a month ago to replace a 6 year old rechargeable toothbrush. I primarily use the \\"Clean\\" setting which gives 2 minutes of brushing with a 30 second interval reminder tone to move to the next quadrant. I find this feature very useful. The brushing cycles per second are much greater than my older unit and this does a great job in removing any residue on the teeth after flossing. This product comes with two brushing heads. I prefer the smaller head as I find it easier to maneuver into and brush confined areas. I occasionally use the UV sanitizing feature but really have no way of telling if it is of any benefit and will probably discontinue it's use. The end results of a 2 minute \\" Clean\\" cycle is a much cleaner feel than the older sonic technology.

  412. We used a Sonicare for 8 years and if the on/off rubber switch hadn't finally disintegrated, might have used it for 8 more. The older screw-on brush model is still available but this one is slimmer with more bells and whistles. Yeah, right, we needed more bells and whistles to brush our teeth.<br /><br />First thing out of the box you find one regular adult brush. The second one is a small round baby brush? If you want an additional adult brush for the spouse, you have to buy it separately. Amazon's writeup is frankly deceptive! We decided we would just use it till it wears out.<br /><br />We have used this Phillips model for about 6 weeks and neither of us would recommend it! As a matter of fact, my wife insisted I write this review she is so unhappy. Why? It is almost impossible to take the brush off the shaft. I can't grip the shaft or even the brush at the base of the bristles where it is wider and pull it off with thumb and forefinger, it takes the whole hand! No wonder it comes with an ultraviolet light to disinfect it. This is beyond ridiculous! I can see how the shaft might have come off in some of the other reviews, the pull required to remove the brush is enormous. My wife can't remove her brush at all, I have to. And she is definitely not enamored with my gripping the whole brush to pull it off. Someone with arthritis would find it impossible. I wish I had stayed with the older screw on brush model and I recommend anyone considering this model do the same.<br /><br />On the other hand, it does as good a job cleaning the teeth as the old model we wore out. And we don't use the other features.<br /><br />Update:<br />A year on I'm more generous with my review. The tooth brushes are still not easily removed, my wife has to use a metal gizmo to pry hers off, but they are a bit easier to remove for me. Cleaning is superb. The only other nit I have is the ease of hitting the selection button for all the other speeds.
  413. I've been a sonicare user for many years and this new model is the best by far. worth the price. [...]
  414. I've used an older model of the Sonicare toothbrush for the past two years and I love it. My teeth are really clean and my dentist approves.<br /><br />The FlexCare Plus is even better. The features have been improved and they've added a gum massage function that's terrific.<br /><br />The one problem I had with the older model was that when you selected what function you wanted - sensitive, regular or quick brush - you couldn't tell for sure that you had selected correctly. They fixed that in this new one. You can now easily select what mode you want and it stays highlighted on the brush.<br /><br />I've loved my older Sonicare and this one is even better. Highly recommended!
  415. Since no one else is writing a review.. or a long one that is.. here it is. I've been looking around for a good electric toothbrush and I've heard many bad things about the older models of sonicare such as mold build up/gunk build up/stale water (which is why i ultimately settled on this model, newest and no nooks & crannies to clean). So I did some research on Sonicare models and I found out this is the latest and most improved model and looks great. If you're wondering how it cleans, it's pretty much a vibrating toothbrush that you go back and forth at a angle towards your teeth (with some pressure applied for maximum clean) at a forward and back motion. You clean the front side of your top portion of your teeth's, then the inside, then switch to the bottom front, then the innards of your front teeth and finally you clean the enamels of your teeth's for the top side and bottom side for a complete clean. Travel case, UV sanitizer, Travel Charger all seem sturdy, but has a plastic feel to it, travel case is pretty hard so thats good. Also comes with two brush heads, one of them is smaller (no clue why). Pros: 1. Looks great, nice and slim 2. Very easy to use, one button for on and off and another to switch modes 3. Very easy to attach and detach brush heads. There will be a light space between the brush head and unit when you fully attach it. 4. Very easy to clean the brush head and the unit itself, run it thru warm water and UV sanitizer for additional cleaning 5. Long battery life (3 weeks) 6. Comes with travel case + charger for those that needs to take this on trips but you'll have to buy your own adapter to charge in other countries. a. I don't know if this is a con or pro but the unit is slightly loud, but not to the point where you'll wake up your whole family, just a normal whirling sound. Con: 1. very uncomfortable initial use but you'll get use to it (mainly because of how it vibrates and it can irritate your gum, again, it all about getting use to it, and don't apply too much pressure towards your teeth or it will hurt, a little bit will do). 2. High price 3. Expensive brush heads compared to Oral b. 4. \\"Stuff\\" will come flying out, so it is a bit messy when you use this. Thats about it for cons, when I have more problems with the unit I will edit. TIPS: 1. Charge it the second you get it for 24 hours for a full charge (last three weeks, maybe longer) 2. Buy more brush heads to share with family members, very easy to detach and clean. Conclusion: It's a great investment if you're a 'lazy' brusher and just want machine to do all the work for you (since good manual brushing can produce good results as well, at least comparable). If you have the money + you're a little lazy + you don't mind replacing brush heads that are a tad more expensive than Oral B's and your manual toothbrushes then... this is a great buy!! I recommend.
  416. I've had the last version of this Sonicare FlexCare for 2 years now. This was my first experience using an electric toothbrush, so I did not know what to expect.<br /><br />This one has a Gum Care mode, which previously with the electric toothbrush I've had is Max Care, which is 2 minutes of Clean, and 1 minute of Massage, so the options are changed alittle by name. The layout of your options is alittle different too.<br /><br />I prefer this new one. They are all in line. I love the idea of having different options. Most times I use just the Clean Mode, and sometimes I will run it twice.<br /><br />I like knowing I have brushed my teeth the recommended amount of time. It is alot less strain on your hand and arm using an electric toothbrush too.<br /><br />The first time I used it, I ran the Sensitive mode, just to see how hard it would be on my teeth,or how hard it would be to get used to. The first few times I used it, it did kind of tickle, but it takes very little time to adjust to using this. In fact, I look forward to using it!<br /><br />The most dramatic thing happened tho. I had this dark spot on one of my upper teeth,in the upper right hand corner, near the gum line. Soon after using the Sonicare Flexcare electric toothbrush the spot disappeared.<br /><br />I was always self conscious about the spot, so this certainly has made me feel more confident when I smile. I think your smile is one of the first things, if not the first thing people will notice when they look at you, so to have that added confidence is very important.<br /><br />I do change the brush heads every 3 months like they recommend. They are alittle pricey, but I do notice the difference when Iam using a new brush head, or closer to when I first have changed it, to when it's closer to the 3 month change.<br /><br />To me, it's worth the expense of replacing the brush heads, because what would be the point of using this electric toothbrush, if Iam not going to use it correctly?<br/><br />For me, this Sonicare Flexcare electric toothbrush has made my teeth alot whiter, given my smile confidence, which in turn has given me confidence. I can't afford dental insurance, so to me, this Sonicare Flexcare electric toothbrush is my dental insurance.<br /><br />I know I will never go back to using a manual toothbrush again! You think a manual toothbrush is doing a good job of cleaning your teeth, but it takes using this Sonicare Flexcare electric toothbrush to see that it wasn't. I know I never had such dramatic results ever using a manual toothbrush.<br /><br />I just leave my unit plugged in, so that I know it's always read to go. Everytime I use my toothbrush, after I have cleaned my teeth, I take the brushhead off, rinse it, then I put it into the small area where the UV Sanitizer is, press that button, which turns on the blue light to sanitize the brush head. I just leave it in there til the next time I brush my teeth. That way, I always know my brush head has been sanitized. I love having the UV Sanitizer. Who wants a germy brush head, that will then go into your mouth to clean your teeth?<br /><br />The unit comes with stickers to remind you to change your brush head, but I just put in in my planner every 3 months, to remind me to change my brush head. When Iam on my last brush head, I order or buy new ones.<br /><br />I think this Sonicare Flexcare electric toothbrush is well worth the price. My dad who recently turned 82, just had all his teeth pulled in May, 2009, to get dentures.<br /><br />After hearing about his ordeal, and seeing his difficulty in eating with dentures, I know I want to keep my teeth as healthy as possible, to possibly avert having to go through the same thing. I want to keep my own teeth as long as possible.<br /><br />I definitely do not want to have to go through what he went through!!

  423. This brush fixes previous design flaws of the Sonicare electric toothbrushes. My E-series brush (which used a NiCad battery and had the screw-on brush head) recently went out on me. So I decided to purchase a new Sonicare brush. Let me talk about the reasons this brush is the best on the market for oral health:<br /><br />(1) The textured bristles along with the 31,000 vibrations per minute not only remove plaque on the surface of the teeth, but effectively penetrate several millimeters below the gumline to break up plaque and kill bacteria. The only thing that effectively delivers a plaque-reducing and bacteria-killing mechanism even deeper into the gumline is an oral irrigator.<br /><br />(2) It uses a lithium-ion battery. Lithium-ion batteries are more powerful and don't have a charge memory like older batteries do.<br /><br />(3) It comes with an enclosed case for the brush head. Let's be realistic, bathrooms are filthy places. Flushing the toilet with the lid up can spray fecal particulate in a 6 foot radius. With the enclosure for the brush heads, they are not only protected from this, but they may also be sanitized by the UV light that comes with the unit. I don't suggest using the UV light every time you brush, as that may (read: WILL) prematurely age the bristles. Once every 3 days is a better suggestion.<br /><br />(4) The brush head simply snaps on. On the older E-series Sonicare brushes, the screw on heads would become absolutely filthy and black with toothpaste residue and who knows what else. Who want's to maintain a toothbrush like they would a car engine? The new brush heads snap on, have no place for debris to be trapped, and are ready to go.<br /><br />(5) Automatic timer- The manual shows how to segregate your mouth into quadrants. The brush has a timer for each quadrant (outside diameter of top teeth, inside diameter of top teeth, outside diameter for bottom teeth, and inside diameter for bottom teeth). On the &#34;Gum Care&#34; setting, it gives you the timer for these quadrants, along with an additional minute for other areas of the mouth that need attention (definitely the tongue, cheeks, and chewing surfaces of the teeth).<br /><br />So in review, this is the most powerful brush Sonicare currently makes (The Diamond series isn't any more powerful). Its incredibly hygienic due to the snap on head, brush enclosure, and UV light. It also promotes proper brush time due to it's timers.<br /><br />I estimate this product to last two to three years based on brushing twice daily.
  424. This is the best toothbrush I have ever used for my teeth. It also makes brushing fun for me as well. When I was finished brushing I felt like I just left the dentist and I could not stop rubbing my tongue against my teeth it was like I just got my braces off because of the fact of how smooth my teeth were. Yea its kinda expensive but if you think about the going rate for a cavity its worth it in the end. If you have the money then buy this because its really like no other as far as taking care of your teeth.

The new toothbrush still wouldn't charge. Then they decided to try another new toothbrush. This time it worked. The whole rigmarole took 4 months. I will have a cheaper model next time.

A web search provides a more problematic assessment of the long-term value this purchase.

  445. I absolutely LOVE this tooth brush. I've been using this tooth brush for about 3 years and love it as much today as I did 3 years ago. Prior to being a proud Sonicare owner, I used the Oral-B electric tooth brush. I went looking for a new brush for two reasons: one, the Oral-B brush heads always accumulated a gross slime inside of them, that really grossed me out. Who wants to put slime in their mouth when they are trying to CLEAN their teeth? Not I. The second reason I went looking for a new toothbrush, is that I really wanted a UV sanitizer for the toothbrush heads. Again, going back to not wanting to put something gross and loaded with germs in my mouth with the intention of cleaning. I solved both of these issues with this Sonicare, and much more!<br /><br />To begin with, there is no gross slime getting stuck in these heads, and the UV sanitizer is amazing. I have read some other reviews that mentioned that daily use of the UV sanitizer can be cumbersome. I don't find this to be an issue at all. It does take a full 10 minutes to complete a full sanitization session, but I just turn on the sanitation while I am showering and/or flossing- my regular morning routine, and by the time I am ready to brush, my heads are nice and sanitized =). Other reviewers have also mentioned that the brush heads need to be perfectly aligned in the sanitizer for the door to close, but I have never had an issue of them not being \\"aligned\\" correctly. I just plop um on the peg, facing any direction and they fit perfectly! The brush heads come in 2 sizes, small and large, and one of each is included in the package, and I use the large ones and have still never had any issue with them fitting in the sanitizer.<br /><br />Successfully meeting my 2 requirements for being happy with my new tooth brush, the Sonicare went above and beyond when it comes to the actual brushing. It truly is a revolutionary sort of \\"sonic\\" vibration. The Oral-B brush I used before just vibrated, this tooth brush seems to be a much more precise and advanced movement that vibrates with purpose. Its nearly impossible to explain the sensation of the Sonicare, but it truly cannot compare it to my old Oral-B. After using the this Sonicare for awhile, I went on vacation and grabbed my old Oral-B. When it came time to use it, I felt like the Oral-B didn't clean my teeth at all! If felt clunky inside my mouth, and the vibrating felt almost useless. The Sonicare really leaves my teeth CLEAN; like just after a dental cleaning clean feeling.<br /><br />I really like the different brushing mode options. 'Refresh' is the 1 minute option, perfect for when I am in a rush. 'Clean' is the 2 minute option, that I use most often. 'GumCare' takes 3 minutes, the first 2 minutes of this mode are just like clean, and the last minute is more of the 'massage' feature, which is a bit softer and is meant to use for brushing your gums. I use the 'GumCare' option at night when I have the time. Then there is the just 'massage' feature. All of these options have an amazing slight pause every 30 seconds, that you use to make sure you are spending equal time in each quadrant of your mouth. I know other reviewers have mentioned that the programming of the brush modes can be annoying, but honestly it is just pushing one button next to the name of the program you wish to use at that time. I know some people might want to set it for the one they like and have it always use that option, but me personally, I like to use different modes at different times, so it would annoy me more if it was set to one and I couldn't change it as easily as I can now.<br /><br />Another really cool thing about this brush is that it comes with 2 different chargers! One has the sanitizer attached to it, and the other one it for travel and does not come with a sanitizer. This toothbrush also comes with a travel case, and brush head covers, which is really cool. Also, the heads have a little plastic circle on it that comes in a few different colors, which is great for couples who share the toothbrush- each with a different color head.<br /><br />I am a bit confused about the difference between the NiCad battery and the Li-ion battery. The newer models have the Li-ion which is supposed to mean that the brush will run longer on a single charge, and won't develop a memory by leaving it on the charging stand. However, I had the older model first and noticed that the newer one doesn't hold a charge as long. However, I had to purchase this newer one because my other battery eventually died, so hopefully this one will have a longer shelf-life, even if that means more charges in-between.<br /><br />I love this toothbrush VERY much, and strongly recommend it to everyone. One more thing I have to mention, ever since I began using this brush, my dentist tells me at every cleaning that I am plaque and tarter free! I really believe that I have this tooth brush to thank for that. =)ferent colors, which is great for couples who share the toothbrush- each with a different color head.<br /><br />I am a bit confused about the difference between the NiCad battery and the Li-ion battery. The newer models have the Li-ion which is supposed to mean that the brush will run longer on a single charge, and won't develop a memory by leaving it on the charging stand. However, I had the older model first and noticed that the newer one doesn't hold a charge as long. However, I had to purchase this newer one because my other battery eventually died, so hopefully this one will have a longer shelf-life, even if that means more charges in-between.<br /><br />I love this toothbrush VERY much, and strongly recommend it to everyone. One more thing I have to mention, ever since I began using this brush, my dentist tells me at every cleaning that I am plaque and tarter free! I really believe that I have this tooth brush to thank for that. =)

  449. The Sonicare Flexcare toothbrush is so much better than the Sonicare Elite (and all other E Series) model. No more having to clean out the gunk on the toothbrush. The brush heads for this latest model are also a lot cheaper than with their previous models. Since I have braces, I need to replace brush heads sooner than most people, so saving money on these brush heads is a plus.   454. I have been a Sonicare user for more years than I can remember. My original Sonicare unit, not made by Philips, finally died. I replaced it a year ago with the Flexcare Plus. I called Philips Customer Service to get it replaced and after holding on the line for an extended time period and extensive questioning, I was told to expect a replacement unit in ten days. That remains to be seen. In any case, Philips has taken a very high quality product and, frankly, ruined it. The new version is no where near the quality of the original Sonicare and that is a shame. It is highly unlikely I would ever buy a Philips brand Sonicare ever again. I definitely would not recommend purchasing it. For the price, it is of extremely poor quality!! It is now May 2012, roughly 15 months after receiving the replacement, and it has now quit working. I'm replacing it with their Easy Clean model, but I expect that it will probably quit working in a year. I have learned my lesson--not spend a lot of money on Sonicare. Get the cheapest unit that does the job you want and expect it to fail within a year. That seems to be Philips' product life cycle. I'm told the Oral-B is not much better in quality, so I'm stuck with Sonicare until I can find a better product. If you buy it, be forewarned that it will fail.

I can't imagine spending this kind of money on an appliance and have it work for less than 60 days. In this economy, who can afford to spend $150 on a disposable toothbrush - not me! I do hope it was just a dud.<br />[[ASIN:B002CVTVVY Philips Sonicare FlexCare Plus, Rechargeable Toothbrush]]<br />UPDATE: So I gave Philips another chance because as long as it was working, I really like how well it cleans my teeth. The second brush didn't even last 4 weeks. It's been returned and I'm moving onto a different brand.
  459. I've had my Sonicare Flex Care Plus for over a month now and my mouth feels cleaner than it ever has. I use the quad pacer feature in the Gum Care mode and it gives me four 30 second intervals followed by four 15 second intervals. It came with all kinds of stuff so I put away the case and the travel charger. I'm sure I'll bust them out when we go out of town! I can't imagine being without my Sonicare for even one night.   465. I had an Oral B many years ago and hardly used it because I never felt like it did as good a job as my manual toothbrush. On a recent visit to the dentist with my 8 year old son, the hygienist recommended he use a Sonicare as he wasn't getting the job done. She said we could save money and buy the kids version but we decided to get this model and then the whole family would use it. So glad we did, as the four of us love it, even the little kids. We bought packs of extra brushes and the kids use the little brush heads. After the very first use, I wasn't sure how well it was really doing. But now after a couple weeks of twice a day use, I can really see and feel the difference it has been making. It really leaves your teeth feeling like something effective has been done, and with such little effort. I'm really looking forward to going back to the dentist in November and hearing what the hygienest has to say about the state of my teeth. I think that will be a telltale sign of how this thing has done. I drink espresso and eat tomatoes daily, and drink wine often, so I figured this would be a good investment to help keep my teeth in as good of shape as possible. It definitely does take some getting used to, especially learning how to NOT have spit/toothpaste sputter out of your mouth, but it doesn't take long. So far, I think this is a very beneficial product.

  496. This toothbrush is fabulous! My first electric toothbrush and I did a lot of research before purchasing this particular model. It comes with a regular-sized brush head and also a small brush head; I purchased additional brush heads, as I did not care for the smaller one and both my husband and I are using this model. It is easy to use and has several other (four more, I think) settings for additional mouth care...especially like the refresher one which gives you a quick one-minute go-over. My teeth feel like I've just had them cleaned at the dentist!! Such a good feeling!! I love the sanitizer that cleans your brush heads when you are done using them for the day. You simply pop them onto the pegs, making sure that the brush head is facing the center, close the door and push the green button...the ultra-blue light lets you know that the cleaning has begun and it takes all of ten minutes! So simple and nice to know that your brush is clean for the next day. It also is equipped with a 30-second tone to let you know when to move on with the cleaning from one area of your mouth to another. The booklet gives you an example of how to clean your teeth using different quadrants, but however you decide to do it, the whole idea is to use 4 30-second quadrants to clean your entire mouth in a 2 minute period. The brush head and holder are easy to clean and the item seems to hold a charge for quite some time before recharging. A recharging unit is also included with the total package...toothbrush holder w/sanitizer built in, two brush heads and a charger. Takes up very little space at all. The reason for the four stars instead of five is a small matter but I feel it would be nice if Phillips could correct this somehow - the tone that is used for reminding that the 30 seconds are up is quite soft and gentle...I have no problem hearing it but for someone who has hearing that is not quite that keen anymore, it is truly difficult to hear the beep. It would be nice if it were a bit louder is all that I'm saying. I'm find that the brush head is wearing fast, also, but it still seems to be doing a good job. It's easy to buy replacement heads at Amazon or Walmart for this particular model. My husband and I are very pleased with the results that this model provides and it's very easy to take care of. Would definitely recommend this item!

  518. This is our third Sonicare--our 2nd one was still alive when we sent it to the farm because it wouldn't hold the charge on long trips. And it had served us well for 12 years. I notice that food never gets stuck in the brush--it's magic. And our teeth always feel so clean. I was happy to get a travel charger with this model as well. One problem we both have--the on/off button is in a place where we frequently hit it by accident which is annoying. Having said that, it wouldn't stop me from buying it in the future (12 years from now-Ha!) But it would be nice if the company saw this complaint--I'm sure there are others, and fixed it! I guess I should write them, too.
  519. your mouth is the source of bacteria, not the toothbrush head. These bacteria are what make human bites so infection prone. just dry off the bristles on a towel, nothing more is needed.

I do this so other Amazon users can get a real feel for the life of the product. You can look at my review which will be close to my purchase date and tell how the product is doing as time passes. I am not associated with any company and all opinions are my very own.<br /><br />UPDATE: It has been about 8 months since we purchased this toothbrush.   529. Don't waste your money on this brush. It stopped working 2 years and 8-9 months after I purchased it. Surprise surprise - the warranty is only for 2 years! We were extremely careful with this brush (it's almost $200 after all!), but it still broke. When I contacted Sonicare, they explained that there is a known issue where the brush stops vibrating after a while. They explained that there was no way to repair the brush, and they wouldn't replace it since the warranty was only for two years. I missed the warranty by about 9 months. They then offered me a pathetic 15% off coupon (only works with their store) and were frankly rather rude. Think about it - the average cost of a toothbrush is $1-2. That means if you change your brush every 3 months as recommended by dentists, you're spending between $4-8 a year. Since this toothbrush only lasted about 33 months for us, we spent nearly $200 in that period (including brush heads - they're not cheap). Had we used traditional toothbrushes, we would have spent between $11-22 during that period.<br /><br />Do the math and think about it - for a toothbrush that WILL break, it's just not worth it. Let me also mention that even though I cleaned the brush religiously, the bottom of it became coated with mold. It's just gross after a while. I would NOT purchase this brush again. Also, feel free to do a web search - lots of people have this problem. This is just not worth it for a brush that will break.

Purchased originally in August 2012, had the first problem in April 2013 (got a replacement handle from Sonicare), and now having the same problem again. I'm guessing Sonicare will replace it again (either the handle or the charger, or both), but it's still a hassle having the product only go 7-8 months without a problem. Possibly a charger issue (they only replaced handle last time), but even then, the charger is still less than 2 years old.<br /><br />Update 11-19-13: Sonicare sending a replacement handle and a return label for the old handle. Customer service has been great, but this will be my third handle in less than 2 years. Checked the old handle on both chargers (wall and travel) and got the same results: Two beeps, pause, third beep, with charging light on handle going from green to orange and toothbrush starting and stopping erratically, so problem seems to be the handle.

  568. It Did. The Sonicare Flexcare Plus is a step better than the Healthy White Sonicare I have been using.<br /><br />When I found that the Amazon Vine program was offering the newest Sonicare toothbrush, I grabbed one, and it is a great find. Here's what I think about the newest version of Sonicare:<br /><br />PROS:<br /><br />1. The FlexCare Plus appears to be gentler than the previous model, but my teeth still get that dentist-clean feeling.<br /><br />2. The brush's \\"engine\\" slows after two minutes for a single minute of gum massage that feels great. Philips says that water is pulsed during cleaning to provide better cleaning between teeth, and that may account for the clean feeling after gum massage.<br /><br />3. There are brief pauses, as with previous versions, to alert you when you've cleaned a quadrant and need to move to the next.<br /><br />4. The UV brush sterilizer is built into the brush's base rather than being an independent unit. Thus, I no longer have two units that need plugging in, but only a single. I now do not have to remove a plug to be able to plug in a hair dryer.<br /><br />5. The battery may last longer than previous models. Certainly you get more brushes from a single charge, so you can take the brush traveling without worrying about having to recharge it.<br /><br />CONS:<br /><br />OK, this is nit-picking, but I miss the tabs that allowed me to open the base to roll the cord for storage. I had to roll the cord by pushing it into the storage area . . . a bit more difficult than on the model that opened up completely but certainly not worth subtracting a star.<br /><br />This is my fourth Philips sonicare, and, as far as I'm concerned, it's the best yet. I highly recommend the FlexCare Plus.
  569. I have owned a Sonicare toothbrush (for about two years and found very easy to use, absolutely reliable, and very thorough in its brushing (i.e., my dentist compliments me on my teeth and gums). This model is an update to an earlier model and in most cases, changes are minor - a good product is made somewhat better. The features I like are still there, namely it signals you every 30 seconds when it is time to move to another part of your mouth and the model also includes a separate base you can use while traveling. Like its predecessor, the toothbrush seems to hold a charge well, though I think you would have to go a couple of weeks using the brush two-three times a day to wear it out.<br /><br />The one completely new feature here is the UV Sanitizer, which is easy to use (basically put brush inside, close a door, and hit a button). I have no idea how well this actually works to sanitize a brush and whether it really is necessary to protect yourself from putting germs back into your mouth that you may have put onto your own brush a few hours before.<br /><br />This really is a good product that does what it is designed to -- i.e., thoroughly clean teeth and massage gums in the process. It is well worth having, though I wouldn't mind having the option of buying the unit without the sanitizer so as to make the unit smaller.

I leave charger under the sink until it vibrates and tells me to charge it. never have to take charger on trips because it lasts at least three weeks. i use the sensitive heads with it.
