I am currently wearing braces and am very happy I have this toothbrush, gives me the comfort of knowing I effortlessly reach all the corners.<br /><br />If my toothbrush would break tomorrow, I would order the same one again without thinking twice!
  594. Replacement heads are more expensive than I prefer, but after a root canal I opted for this and I believe it was worth it.
  595. The newest Sonicare is just as wonderful and effective as the others with a few new features. In addition to the regular clean, sensitive, and massage modes, there are now \\"Gum Care\\" and \\"Refresh\\" modes. These are all just slightly different speeds and durations but everyone can choose their favorite. In all cases, the motor is very quiet and the slim handle is easy to hold. The Plus model has a sleeker appearance with the various speeds not showing until you press the \\"mode\\" button to light up the choices.<br /><br />I love the way my teeth feel after using the Sonicare and I brush longer than I used to with a manual toothbrush. My dentists says my gums are really healthy, too. The battery stays charged for three weeks making it very handy to take on trips, plus there is a nifty carrying case. The toothbrush comes with one regular and one small brush head. You also get a sanitizing unit that cleans your brush head in only ten minutes. Highly recommended.
  596. I've received this toothbrush last week from Amazon/Drugstore.com and it's great. My dentist recommend this toothbrush after my old one which was an Oral B went kaput. This Sonicare Flexcare Plus is a big improvement over my old Oral B. My teeth are super slick when I rub my tongue over them and shiny. I love the compact tooth head. At first I wasn't sure if I had the right toothbrush as I didn't see the 5 brushing mode display not knowing that the text will appear after the toothbrush is fully charge and when I hit the select button. The text will disappear a couple of seconds after the toothbrush is turn off and reappear after you hit the select button to select one of the brushing mode. It was confusing when the picture on the box shows the 5 brushing mode but after you open up the box you see this nice silver finsih with no text. This is a fancy little gizmo, a BIG upgrade from my 5 or 6 years old Oral B Braun power toothbrush. I can't wait to go in for my next dental checkup to see how well this toothbrush remove the plaque from my teeth. This is a big keeper. I highly recommend this toothbrush. Try to buy this toothbrush when it's on sale if you can.
  597. This is my first battery operated toothbrush. I think that this model is great. It works very well, is comfortable to use, and has a timer to help me keep track of how long to brush. The ultimate test result will be when I go in for my next dental cleaning. I would not hesitate to recommend it. Update: I went for my semi-annual dental cleaning last month. Great news to report - my dentist was amazed at how well my gums have improved. Excellent product!
  598. This is my third Sonicare toothbrush. I've owned the Elite and Intelliclean and other brands of sonic toothbrushes and I must say, the Flexcare Plus is the best one yet.<br /><br />Out of the box, I see that the handle is slimmer than the others, sleeker and much more attractive; and the cleaning modes are displayed on the handle. It's easy to switch modes and there's no need to guess which mode the unit is in.<br /><br />It is easy to clean. Not all Sonicare brushes are. Some sport messy toothpaste dispensers (Intelliclean) or difficult to reach pit (Elite).<br /><br />The only problem I encounter is the brush head must fit on the handle in a certain direction -- you have to fit it on a rod, which is flat on one side. The Elite screws on, which is easy for the kids. This one takes a little more precision, which isn't difficult, but maybe not something for younger kids, those with poor eyesight or shaky hands.<br /><br />***ACCESSORIES***<br /><br />Oh my. So many accessories.<br /><br />FOUR COLORED RINGS, to distinguish the toothbrush heads -- choose one for you and one for your spouse.<br /><br />TWO BRUSH HEADS with sanitary covers.<br /><br />A NICE, HARD PLASTIC TRAVEL CASE which holds the handle and two brush heads -- the most attractive I've seen with the Sonicare toothbrushes.<br /><br />TWO CHARGERS: a small travel charger and a full size charger that is attached to a UV sanitizer. My other Sonicare brushes did not come with extra travel chargers.<br /><br />***CLEANING MODES***<br /><br />Flexcare has Quadpacer technology, which means it beeps every 30 seconds to remind us to move to another quadrant. That feature may be disabled, but I find it most useful. Intellicare includes Quadpacer technology. I believe some Elite models have Quadpacer, but mine did not.<br /><br />There are four different cleaning modes included. Intellicare has two modes and Elite has one.<br /><br />CLEANING mode: 2 minutes of normal cleaning.<br /><br />GUM CARE mode: 2 minutes of normal cleaning plus 1 additional minute to concentrate on the gums (Quadpacer beeps every 15 seconds for the gum care minute). The gum cleaning is more gentle. This is my preferred mode.<br /><br />REFRESH mode: 1 minute.<br /><br />SENSITIVE mode: 2 minutes. More gentle cleaning.<br /><br />MASSAGE mode: 2 minutes. I can feel larger, slower circular vibrations than in any other mode. Feels like a back massage in the mouth.<br /><br />***UV SANITIZER***<br /><br />The UV sanitizer can sanitize two brush heads at the same time. Turn it on and it sanitizes for 10 minutes then automatically turns off. I thought maybe my toothbrush would be all wet inside, but it dries out my toothbrush for me. This the only Sonicare toothbrush I've owned with a UV cleaning feature and I think it's a wonderful addition.<br /><br />PROS:<br />+ comes with two brush heads and colored rings<br />+ nice travel case (best I've seen for Sonicare)<br />+ comes with small travel charger in addition to standard charger<br />+ standard charger has a UV sanitizer for two brush heads<br />+ Quadpacer technology to pace your cleaning<br />+ four separate modes -- easy to read and set<br />+ slimmer, sleek handle<br /><br />CONS:<br />- doesn't dispense toothpaste (Intelliclean does, but I honestly didn't care for that feature. It's really not a con for me, but perhaps it is for some people.)<br />- brush head isn't easy for young children or those with disabilities to attach<br /><br />***SUMMARY***<br /><br />Sonicare cleans teeth so much better than regular brushing alone. My dentist and my children's dentists always marvel at how clean our teeth are. It's really the toothbrush, because when we don't use Sonicare, the dentists notice. The question is which Sonicare to choose.<br /><br />For young kids, I'd go with the Elite. It's easier for them to change brush heads, and it's simpler and less expensive. They don't understand the concept of the Quadpacer technology (at least my kids didn't); and rather than using the appropriate mode, they just play with it.<br /><br />For adults, Flexcare Plus is the way to go. Sleek, easy to clean, a variety of modes, UV sanitizer -- it is my favorite sonic toothbrush of all time.nic toothbrush of all time.

The price is a little high, but is well worth it as I find its use to be more entertaining than a chore and look forward both morning and night to using it. I have been using Sonicare Toothbrushes for years and this one is pretty similar to the last one that I had with the exception of the extra gum care setting and the fact that the indicators are not visible unless you are using it which gives a sleeker look as compared to the older versions. I have not had a single cavity since I started using Sonicares and I have a great checkup every 6 months even though I only actually brush once a day.   601. If you want a toothbrush that really gets your teeth squeaky clean a Philips Sonicare is the toothbrush for you. My first Sonicare toothbrush was a more basic model, the [[ASIN:B0019ZEVZU Philips Sonicare R710 HealthyWhite Power Toothbrush]] and it did an excellent job. This one is a lot fancier and has a great \\"high tech\\" look with the UV Brush Head Sanitizer that lights up with a spacey blue color when it's being used. The brush handle itself also lights up showing the different settings such as Clean, Gum Care, Refresh, Sensitive and Massage. Each is a little different speed although some are so close it's difficult to feel a lot of difference with the toothbrush in your mouth. The only thing that I wish was different is that you have to turn the toothbrush off to change the settings. It would have been nice to be able to change while the brush was running.<br /><br />As far as cleaning your teeth, you just can't beat a Sonicare. I've had Braun and Oral-B toothbrushes in the past and they just don't come close to the Sonicare in the way they clean my teeth. You know that feeling after you come out of the dentist's office for a cleaning where your teeth have that polished, smooth feeling when you run your tongue over them? Even after the first time using this one my teeth felt that way. Another nice thing was that my gums don't bleed when I use this toothbrush. For as long as I can remember my gums have bled after brushing my teeth, even when brushing by hand. I thought with the way this brush moves so fast that it would cause bleeding too but for some reason it doesn't.<br /><br />This toothbrush comes with 2 ProResults brush heads, the UV Brush Head Sanitizer, 1 travel charger, 2 hygienic travel caps, and 1 hard travel case. I've never taken an electric toothbrush along when I traveled before, I just used the old basic hand toothbrush, but I've become so spoiled and the travel charger takes up so little room that I take this one along. The replacement brushes aren't cheap, but the way this toothbrush cleans my teeth makes them worth the price.<br /><br />I was able to try this toothbrush through the Amazon Vine program or I probably would have gone on using my Philips Sonicare R710 HealthyWhite Power model. (Which another family member was happy to get.) It works just fine and does just as good a job of cleaning my teeth. But this one is really attractive and I love having all the different settings and choices of speeds. The UV cleaner is a nice touch. With the previous model I had to soak the brushes in hydrogen peroxide to sanitize them. And if you're into aesthetics, this one looks really nice on the bathroom counter.   604. My dentist suggested I switch from a manual toothbrush to the Sonicare. I went through one in less than three months, and the second one is already starting to wear. So you have to be prepared for a pretty big investment in brush heads after purchasing this toothbrush.<br /><br />Overall, I would recommend this to anyone who is less than diligent with flossing, or if you have problems with staining in between dentist appointments.   615. I have used electric toothbrushes before, but this was my first model that utilized \\"sonic technology.\\" I must say that I am highly impressed. Every time I use this model I walk out of my bathroom feeling as if I just left the dentist. The varying brush modes are a convenient way maximizing your experience, however, you don't have to use them if you do not want to. The charging base is very compact and will sit nicely on the corner of a vanity sink or a small shelf. A feature that is not advertised, but should be, is the fact that you can keep the toothbrush on the charging base so that it constantly has a full charge without adversely effecting the battery. Even without keeping it on the charging base, the battery life is very long, lasting around 3 weeks with moderate (twice a day) usage. The only qualm I have with this product is that it must be plugged into an electrical outlet if you want to use the UV brush sanitizer. I feel as though a battery powered option would have been nice seeing as electrical outlets are typically not very abundant in bathrooms.

  618. My last toothbrush was a Sonicare Elite and that lasted me a good 5.5 years. Unfortunately, I had to toss it out (via e-waste disposer) because of the mold on the handle and the low battery life. Pros: 1) New toothbrush design reduces mold build-up at the base of the brush stem (part where it connects to the handle). The old screw-on type traps water and toothpaste residue and requires me to regular take off the collar to rinse it out properly. 2) The standard ProResults toothbrush head is smaller than the standard one for the Sonicare Elite. It's just slightly bigger than the Elite compact version, which I like. If go for the ProResults compact version, it's even tinier than the Elite compact version, which allows for more focused brushing. 3) Replacement brushes are cheaper for the ProResults toothbrushes. 4) Travel charger is nice and compact. 4) Handle now comes with a battery state of charge indicator. Good for me to have since I take frequent short business trips and rather avoid taking along the travel charger even if it's quite small. Cons: 1) Flexcare handle is much longer than the Elite handle, which results in a larger case. 2) The \\"ProResults\\" label rubs off on my toothbrush after I pull the toothbrush on and off a few dozen times. Not a big deal, but it's the same type of premature failure as the blue colored section of the bristles. I've seen the same thing happen with so many manual toothbrushes that I don't even look at the blue colored section of my ProResults brush and rely on a calendar. Aside: I do the same with my Brita faucet filter because the LED light is flaky. Notes: 1) This version comes with the hard case instead of the strange soft case Flexcare originally shipped with. That's good because I don't think the soft case can properly protect the metal stem sticking out of the handle. Not a pro because this should've been standard. 2) UV sanitizer is probably more gimmick than of real use. This has been discussed by reviewers manytimes already, but to sum it up, it's not really needed because of the germ fighting agents in your toothpaste and it may do more harm than good if bacteria mutate to become more UV resistant. I only bought it because this kit cost me the same as the no-frills one at the time of purchase. 3) Battery for the Flexcare+ seems to last about a week longer (3.5 weeks) than my Elite when it was new. Hope this means that the battery lasts longer too. The Elite was still good for about 2-3 days around the end of the 5.5 year.
  619. I love this toothbrush. This new brush is thinner, lighter and has nowhere for the wetness from brushing to accumulate! as compared to my elite toothbrush. I also like the smaller brush head. I would definately recommend this toothbrush even though it is a little on the expensive side.

  634. Update 8-20-2014: Edited my review score to 4-stars from 1-star. The reason is when I called Philips, a nice CS rep named Sarah hooked me up with a new base and three brand new brush heads. Even though my unit was out of warranty (though the closeness of the expiration date had a lot to do with it, I'm sure). This is another lesson as to why when you get in touch with a company, be friendly, be patient, and 9/10 times, they'll do right by you because they value you as a customer. Big props to Philips for standing behind this product. A week with a real toothbrush has just about killed me (my teeth hate me, my wife hates me, my wife's teeth hate me... who would have thought a toothbrush could take away so much hate? heh).<br /><br />Like a lot of others leaving negative reviews, I'm a long-time Sonicare user. The model I bought from my dentist almost a decade ago worked for seven years before the metal rod that vibrates the head finally vibrated the rubber seals right off. I wasn't upset, as if I can get a $200 toothbrush to work for seven years (keep in mind, my wife and I use it, twice daily each at a minimum), it was worth the money.<br /><br />So I bought the new one on July 13, 2012. As of August 16, 2012, the toothbrush no longer charges. No matter what. I've even tried using the travel base and the old toothbrush's base. Nothing. For an hour or two there was a few small flashes of light, but now it's completely dead. Philips usually has a decent warranty, so I came back to look at my order and find out if it's still covered.<br /><br />Of course, the toothbrush died three days after the two year warranty period expires. I'm very upset about this, not just because it's an inconvenience (for anyone who is used to one of these, going back to a manual toothbrush is not pleasant at all), but because as I'm looking through these reviews to see if I'm the only unlucky one, I'm seeing a lot of customers in my situation. Too many, to be honest.<br /><br />I'll bug Philips first, but if they don't offer to help me, I'll find another brand, or get used to a manual toothbrush again (yeah, I know, first-world problems). Heck, I'll even agree to pay $50 or something reasonable to get the base unit's battery replaced, but I'm not paying full price for another one that might only last until days after the warranty expires.fer to help me, I'll find another brand, or get used to a manual toothbrush again (yeah, I know, first-world problems).   649. Love the UV feature and the selection of all the different cleaning modes on this model. Does a great cleaning job. This is the third sonicare toothbrush I have purchased in the past 8 or 9 years. The first sonicare I purchased, I used a couple of years but there were rough edges around the toothbrush(bad design). So I upgraded to the elite which I loved but after several years the battery finally gave out. (bad thing about the elite was inside the handle where inserted the toothbrush, mildew would build up and was very hard to bleach and keep clean.) Love the fact that this new flexcare plus model has a closed handle and the toothbrush goes onto a metal rod so easy to clean. All the sonicare toothbrushes I have used leave your teeth feeling really clean.

  652. I have been using an electronic tooth brush for years, but now that I have tried sonic technology I would NEVER go back! My teeth feel straight-from-the-dentist clean! I now find much less plaque when I floss and I think it is making my teeth whiter! I LOVE MY TOOTHBRUSH!!! Highly recommended!
  653. This is my first mechanical toothbrush. I purchased it after reading several scholarly research articles on the benefits of \\"true\\" sonic action in toothbrushes over manual brushing. I have very good dental health overall, but I'm terrible at making myself floss, and a sonic toothbrush can mitigate some of that neglect. I have been using it for a few weeks now and I can already tell a HUGE difference in my gum health, and several people have remarked that my teeth seem whiter. Though the toothbrush gently increases intensity through the first 10 or so times you use it, my gums bled slightly the first few times I used it - my hygenist said that was actually a good sign at first as long as it didn't continue (it didn't) - it means pockets in your gums that were previously undisturbed are being cleaned. I use the timed brush function, which vibrates distinctively every 30 seconds to tell you to move to the next section of your mouth. It is a bit awkward the first few times because you don't actually \\"brush\\" with the sonicare - you move it evenly across your teeth and gums and the vibration \\"brushes\\" for you, but it quickly becomes easy. The unit is well constructed and very, very simple to use. It took rather a long time to charge up before the first use, but it has had excellent battery life since then. Construction is of very high quality and cleaning is simple. The included instructions are clear. You may want to check what is included in your package before you purchase additional brush heads - my package came with both a generous coupon and an offer related to registering for warranty.
  654. You get two wands with this package. Expect both to break within or close to the warranty period. I have owned these sonicare brushes since they first came out and I have generally been very satisfied but the new design is really weak. Better save your receipt and pray they break within the warranty period or you will be out of luck! And you cannot buy replacement wands only so you will be forced to buy a whole new set. What a ripoff.
  655. Have used various electric teeth cleaning systems for over a decade with mixed success. Brought a earlier version of the Philips Sonic a few years ago. It was the best results of any system. I believe it was due to the lateral (sideways) motion of the head being able to better clean the curved surfaces and between the teeth. The rechargeable failed after about three years and Philips ceased making a 240 voltage version. Forced to revert back to the rotating head style item which produced much poorer results and required more extensive flossing and a combination of nonelectric hand brushing. Sourced the new multi-voltage Philips Sonicare. After a very short period of adjusting the results are excellent. Teeth and gums feel much healthier and need for flossing is reduced. Brought the version with bells and whistles - probably not necessary. Also brush longer than the built in timer - probably not necessary. New head design considerable improvement. Different head size brushes are a useful personal option Tip - let the brush do the work with light pressure and slow movement around the mouth. It is enjoyable to use a tool that produces very good results. Dentist is not happy - no funds to put kids through collage
  656. As a son of a dentist I figured myself for a pretty good caretaker of my teeth but after having neglected my dental checkups for about 3 years, I finally went in and found out I needed some fairly serious work done. I was told I needed to take better care of my teeth which woke me up. Just simply brushing my teeth a couple times/day with an occasional flossing wasn't enough. I did some research online for one of the new electric toothbrushes. After visiting some blogs about them (yes people are actually obsessive about dental care) I chose the Philips Sonicare flexcare plus kit based on the high marks all around from every site I researched. It wasn't cheap but I figured it would last me for years and if it would help keep my teeth then it would be worth it. The sonicare action of the toothbrush took a little getting used to. It vibrates the brush head quickly and pressing gently against the teeth at the gumline makes for a slightly sensitive strange experience at first. I got used to it quickly though and the results are so much better than I expected. My teeth feel truly cleaned after I use the Sonicare brush and it has even whitened my teeth a bit having removed some of the tartar build up discoloration. It's also much more effortless than a traditional manual toothbrush since you simply put the Sonicare brush against the teeth at the gumline and slowly move it across the fronts and backs of the teeth. Much simpler than brushing back and forth at different angles. It also came with a UV light unit that kills bacteria for the brush heads which I find useful and a nice extra with the kit. The brush came with a travel kit that includes a storage container for the brush and heads and portable power charger. That was a great addition and on a recent overseas trip with my wife came in very handy. Overall I'm very pleased with the Philips Sonicare toothbrush and would recommend it to anyone who can afford to spend a bit more for better regulardental care.

  668. This is my 3rd Sonicare and they FINALLY got the head design right. Older models were notoriously hard to clean and would collect water and get mildew. Sonicare has adopted a design similar to Oral-B (the way the brush head attaches to the handle). This model is MUCH easier to keep clean and also has a much smaller diameter handle (probably half the size of the first Sonicare I had). Also comes with a smaller travel charger (though you can make it at least 2 weeks on a full charge).<br /><br />The only con is that the 5 modes are a bit overkill and I somehow often accidentally change out of the normal mode. Otherwise, this is an all around great toothbrush.
  669. I've had this for two years now and absolutely love it! With this brush, you get that fresh from the dentist feeling everyday, and how can you beat that? The UV sanitizer is amazing too; you wouldn't believe how many germs sit on the average toothbrush left in a bathroom. It kills the germs and also just makes a great place to keep the brush heads between brushings to reduce the amount of germs that ever touch them in the first place. The other great thing about this brush is that it has three different settings depending on how much time you have, and I love the massage setting for your gums! Another nice feature is the ability to change out the colored rings at the bottom of the toothbrush heads, allowing you to keep track of which head is yours, so more than one person can use the unit. I think Philips thought of just about everything with this brush, and it definitely holds up to its guarantee of better dental checkups. :)

  672. This is the best dental care product I've ever purchased. The UV light cleaner thing might be more of a gimmick than anything else, but it looks cool. Note that the brushes and actual operation of this model are almost the same as the cheaper [[ASIN:B004M1BO3U Philips Sonicare Hx6511/50 Easy Clean Rechargeable Toothbrush, White]]. The difference is that this model has a slightly more powerful motor (I think - the vibrations are more vigorous), and has the &#34;massage&#34; option which means the amplitude of the vibration is larger (moves more from side to side) and the frequency lower (vibrates slower, but still very fast). This thing removes coffee/tea stains and removes residue from the gumline better than any other toothbrush/electric I've owned, and is comfortable to use.

  690. I purchased this toothbrush from Amazon.com a couple of years ago and have been using it ever since. This toothbrush comes with a couple of different modes and settings such as gum brushing but to be honest I only use one of them for brushing my teeth. This toothbrush has a few helpful features that I do use. One of the helpful features is the UV cleaner. I have to charge my toothbrush about once a week so whenever I do, I take off the brush and put it in the UV cleaner and let that run through to ensure any bacteria is removed from the brush. I also enjoy the timed alerts that tell you after 30 seconds have passed when you are brushing your teeth so that you can move to a different section of your mouth to brush. While the toothbrush vibrates it's just a little sound it makes that tells you 30 seconds have passed and the setting I use it does this 4 times.<br />The only problem I have had was about a year and a half after having it, the battery stopped charging or holding a charge. I contacted Sonicare and because the brush was within the 2 year warranty they immediately shipped me out a new toothbrush that I received in a couple of days.<br />Overall I would recommend this toothbrush to anyone looking for a good quality electric toothbrush. I have had it over 2 years and I am very happy with my purchase.
  691. I bought this toothbrush in August 2012. On January 7, 2015 It stopped working. I realize we are a consume based society but when I pay over $100 for a toothbrush I expect value. The Sonicare is not worth the money. There are numerous design flaws including: The base unit door will stop working. As in you will close the door, press the UV button (which is cute but probably useless) and nothing will happen. I originally thought this was a button problem and Philips replaced the base under warranty. When the 2nd unit started to experience the same issue a few month later is investigated more thoroughly. Turned out to be a cheaply designed mechanical door switch contact Some tinfoil fix it. The toothbrush mode button is positioned to be extremely easy to hit accidentally and you'll be unable to see that the mode has changed while brushing. The OEM attachments are very expensive and usually of poor quality. I've had much better performance and longevity from the generic heads at a 1/3 the price. Finally the toothbrush, base, every inch of the thing quickly fills every crack with dirt and grime. Not that I expect my toothbrush to be a work of art but it should at least not be disgusting. This is a bad product.
  692. Have been using this brush for over a month now ,<br /><br />Pros - Excellent reach, cleaning action & ease of use.<br /><br />Cons - Indian buyers beware that with duties the brush would cost you over INR 10,000/- & it does not ship with spare brush heads.
  693. This toothbrush does a very good job of cleaning your teeth and gums. It is very powerful and leaves your teeth squeaky clean. The brushes look like they are durable too and don't show signs of wear as other brands do soon after you start using them. As said in other reviews, it takes a little getting adjusted to the tickle feeling when brushing certain areas of your mouth. The one drawback is that the brush cycle is set up to break up brushing into 30 second intervals so that you divide up your brushing into 4 areas. However, you have 6 areas to brush if take into account that you still have the flat surface areas of your teeth. That said, you need more time to brush than 2 minutes. The brush completely stops after 2 minutes and you need to restart the cycle again to brush the flat surface areas.
  694. Bought this unit from Amazon in June 2010. The unit has been working wonderfully. I noticed that my teeth are much cleaner and smoother.   698. This unit has spent most of its life in the box. It was given to be by someone who had no use for it. After being told I was out of warranty and the unit was junk, I took it apart to confirm that yes, the main piece inside had separated and is made of cheap Chinese components. It worked great until I had to change a brush head which is the only way that could have broke, despite the fact that I only applied the level of force necessary to remove it and no more. The toothbrush won't charge anymore and it just keeps turning itself on and it won't turn off at all.   706. I have long been wary of electric toothbrushes. I figured I can make do with a traditional toothbrush just fine, and not spend a lot of money on something that would provide minimal benefit. I even brushed off my dentist when they were trying to peddle an electric toothbrush on me, despite minutes earlier applauding my technique. However, I [obviously] changed my mind.<br /><br />I was considering either the Oral-B 5000 or the Sonicare. I did plenty of research on models and specs, and in the end decided on Sonicare. While I have had a friend years ago recommend one, I have tended to prefer Oral-B manual toothbrushes for years, so they were at the top of my list. For Sonicare, I liked how the brush head was more closely related to a traditional toothbrush, rather than a circular shape of Oral-B. Some of the reviews for Oral-B indicated a minor irritation when the toothbrush would stop in the middle of brushing, telling you to move to the next &#34;section.&#34;<br /><br />In the end, I decided to go with Sonicare, despite the cost difference. I have loved the experience since I bought the brush a few months ago! Every time I brush, I feel like I just had a professional cleaning...no joke. I currently am unable to think of any real downsides to the brush. I highly recommend it.

  709. After using this tooth brash for 3+ years I can say that it does great job cleaning my teeth, but I have run into some problems:<br /><br />1. After using &#34;Clean&#34; mode for more than a year I get a gum recession and had to switch to a &#34;Sensitive&#34; mode and be careful around those areas.<br />3. One morning all of a sudden this tooth brash stopped working after 3 years and a month of careful using only at home. Now I have to buy a new one or something similar. Quite expensive if you consider the fact that I have payed almost $150 for something slightly more than 3 years.<br /><br />So, after 3 years of using it I can see that I was paying around $100 a year.

  717. I bought 4 units in October 2010, three for gifts for my close relatives and one for myself. It is a great unit and I loved it. After about 9 months, the unit developed problem, turning on by itself and would not charge properly. I called the customer service and they sent me a replacement unit in a couple of weeks. The replacement unit worked fine for about 6 more months and developed the same problem again. Called the customer service and they sent me another unit. That worked for about 9 months, and then the brush head would not vibrate, I could hear the motor running but it was not making the brush head vibrate. The 24 month warranty just expired and I thought that was it. But just to give it a try, I called the customer service AGAIN, and they did not say anything about the warranty expiration and send me another unit. So this is the 3rd replacement for me. Some of the reviewers here mentioned similar problems like mine but they were happy with the Philips customer service. But I wonder how Philips could say that there are no known problems. They are full of crap, don't want to admit the problem with the unit. But the strange thing is, the other 3 units I gifted are still working without any problem. Looks like the problem is not with all the units but with some random ones. Now I don't know how long this unit is going to last and if it breaks down, whether Philips would send me another one or not. Only time can tell. Also I wonder if Philips is sending reconditioned units (defective units) as replacements but we would never know about that, would we?

  722. The toothbrush is awsome period. I like all the different modes it has. I dont have dental insurance so this brush could save me some money.
  723. I had the same problem with the loose shaft that others are reporting,and fixed it.The problem is with a screw that comes loose where the shaft attaches to the inner body.Here's how to fix it.First run the battery down by continuously restarting when it times out.Even after it has run down it will still buzz for a second when turned on.This took me a good 25 minutes.When battery has run down down take a wide bladed flathead screwdiver to the bottom of the handle.Insert the screwdriver so that the blade fits into the slots and with force,turn the bottom counter-clockwise 1/4 turn.With the toothbrush off push down on the shaft until it pushes out the bottom.Carefully pull out the inside body.Do this over a newspaper or a table as the loose parts may fall out.If you look where the shaft attaches to the handle,there is a small screw holding a 1/4 square bracket to the lower part of the shaft.It will be very loose or not attached at all.Take the screw and the bracket off.Use either loctite or nailpolish and lightly coat the threads of the screw.Insert the screw so that the head is on the flat side of the bracket,and the the threads come through the side with the cylindrical cutout.Using a pair of tweezers set the assembly (rounded side pointing towards the top,flat side towards the bottom.)into the gap where it goes.Using a small philips head screwdriver,(a jewelers screwdiver works great)tighten well.Take the inside (the part you just worked on)and line up the button contacts with the buttons on the outer housing.Slowly push in until it clicks into place.Voil`a ! Your done.Let dry overnight.Now better than new.
  724. A user of the previous model [[ASIN:B005G1GZKC Philips Sonicare Flexcare Plus Rechargable Sonic Toothbrush - DENTAL PROFESSIONAL MODEL HX 6992/03]] (mine had a UV sanitizer as well), and the Oral-B Triumph [[ASIN:B000A7W5DI Oral-B Triumph Professional Care 9400 Power Toothbrush]], I would rate this Philips as the top of the list for premier automatic/electric toothbrushes. The UV sanitizer really is effective for killing microorganisms; the debate is whether this is clinically significant. I look at it like the \\"chicken soup\\" argument - couldn't hurt. The literature is really sparse on whether a sterile toothbrush has significant health effects, but there is a growing body of research that implicates dental bacteria in a variety of systemic diseases and disorders, so a sterile toothbrush is certainly not a negative. The \\"sonic\\" action of this brush is superior (in my opinion) for cleaning over the reciprocal action of the Oral-B, and less likely to damage gums and cause sensitivity.<br /><br />For brushing effectiveness it works great; the various timer modes really are useful, particularly the \\"Refresh\\" mode for a quick brush, and they stay set after you use them, so you don't need to continually select your preferred mode when starting. Brush heads seem to last a long time and are easy to swap out.<br /><br />The \\"update\\" from the previous FlexCare model is slight, but real. The different cycles on the handle are easier to understand and set, it comes with a hard, more protective case (previous was soft), and I think the battery lasts longer (time will tell). It also has a sleeker, less cluttered look on the outside (probably easier to clean/rinse as well). The rubber on the handle is colored differently, and I suspect will show stains less after long use than the pale green of the earlier FlexCare.<br /><br />The \\"minuses\\" to the new model are that the sterilizer no longer indicates if the brushes have been sterilized at the end of the cycle (previously there was a steady green light): you have to remember \\"did I turn it on?\\" The cord is a little more difficult to wind up in the unit to shorten it. The brush heads appear to be almost identical, except the \\"new\\" heads have a very pale blue set of \\"reminder\\" bristles that are supposed to show generally when they need changing, but are hard to tell apart from the pale green \\"normal\\" bristles (on the standard heads) so I suspect are useless for that purpose; just change the brush when the head looks worn.<br /><br />*Not really a toothbrush review, but the Philips packaging for this product is horrible - eight spot-welded plastic plugs, at least three or four of which must be cut, and if you use a sharp instrument (knife, scissors) to open it, which you must, you stand a pretty good chance of lacerating either your skin, the family pet or the furniture. Definitely a worthy candidate for the Oyster Award (given annually by Consumer Reports for difficult-to-open-packages).<br /><br />Overall, a recommended upgrade. Haven't compared it to the Philips DiamondClean [[ASIN:B0052JN7XG Philips Sonicare HX9332/05 Diamondclean Rechargeable Toothbrush]], but the added convenience of the sterilizer (and cheaper price) makes the FlexCare Plus worth considering over the \\"newer\\" Philips, and reading some of the reviews on the design of the Diamondclean I suspect this one is superior.: you have to remember \\"did I turn it on?\\" The cord is a little more difficult to wind up in the unit to shorten it. The brush heads appear to be almost identical, except the \\"new\\" heads have a very pale blue set of \\"reminder\\" bristles that are supposed to show generally when they need changing, but are hard to tell apart from the pale green \\"normal\\" bristles (on the standard heads) so I suspect are useless for that purpose; just change the brush when the head looks worn. *Not really a toothbrush review, but the Philips packaging for this product is horrible - eight spot-welded plastic plugs, at least three or four of which must be cut, and if you use a sharp instrument (knife, scissors) to open it, which you must, you stand a pretty good chance of lacerating either your skin, the family pet or the furniture. Definitely a worthy candidate for the Oyster Award (given annually by Consumer Reports for difficult-to-open-packages). Overall, a recommended upgrade. Haven't compared it to the Philips DiamondClean [[ASIN:B0052JN7XG Philips Sonicare HX9332/05 Diamondclean Rechargeable Toothbrush]], but the added convenience of the sterilizer (and cheaper price) makes the FlexCare Plus worth considering over the \\"newer\\" Philips, and reading some of the reviews on the design of the Diamondclean I suspect this one is superior.

  751. I have owned the Sonicare HX6972 for a couple years now. I LOVE the way it makes my teeth feel, it's 100X better than a manual toothbrush and significantly better than the old Sonicare design with the screw on replacement heads. I typically only use the clean cycle, and it's nice that it beeps at you to remind you which section you're supposed to be brushing but I usually end up ignoring that and doing my own thing. I would definitely recommend buying it. 5 stars on how it brushes and Panasonic Customer Service, 1 star removed because of reliability issues and the design that allows gunk to collect between the brush head and the handle.<br /><br />Pros:<br />+ Keeps teeth significantly cleaner than manual brushing (I've been brushing with a manual brush - see cons - for a couple months and had a 6th month cleaning in which the hygienist commented on some extra scale build up, usually they're in and out of there in no time with no complaints when I've been brushing with the Sonicare and flossing occasionally)<br />+ Also seems to keep gums less irritated, I noticed a significant increase in irritation when going back to the manual toothbrush.<br />+ Has the sanitizing option for the toothbrush head - big improvement over previous versions<br />+ Has lots of neat features for different brushing modes so if you're obsessed with oral hygiene you can get your fix in multiple ways<br />+ Comes with a small base for when you're traveling, that way you can take your toothbrush on all your travels without packing the huge base with the sanitizer in it, worked great without a current converter when I took it to Australia.<br />+ Panasonic customer service is top notch. I recently had to get my handle replaced (see the cons) and they sent me a new one, no questions asked that arrived within a week of me sending them my receipt. The customer service was really polite on the phone, I got an email response confirming they had received my receipt within 5 minutes of me emailing it to them and they didn't make me send back the defective unit before replacing it. They also included a shipping label to send back the defective unit on their dime for proper recycling (gold star for being green friendly assuming they actually recycle it).<br /><br />Cons:<br />- The unit stopped working after about 20 months. It had the ghost behavior that some of the other reviewers have described, meaning that it would turn itself on while on the charger at random times. The malfunctions started out as the unit turning off prior to the full 2 minute brush cycle, and beeping at intervals other than 30s. Then it wouldn't turn on at all unless it was on the charger, in which case it wouldn't turn off. Not great. So I eventually called customer service and had the fantastic experience I mentioned above.<br />- There is a small gap between the brush head and the base that gets a lot of gross gunk in it. You have to take off the brush head and rinse daily to make sure that this doesn't turn into something nasty (worst case: mold) inside your toothbrush. Probably isn't a problem if you're sanitizing the head once a day but if you're like me and you don't pull the head off for a week or so (see the light comments below) be prepared for some pretty gnarly stuff in there. Still better than the old design which had a giant well under the brush head and two small holes leading into that well so that the well collected all sorts of grossness in it.<br />- The light, oh the light. This unit has a pulsing blue light when the sanitizer is on which can light up an entire room at night. If your bathroom is like mine and has any opening into your bedroom you are going to hate this sanitizer. It's bright enough to be a night light and more (I think you could probably use it for a lighthouse light to guide ships to your bathroom on a foggy night). Even the green bars that show the charge level are pretty bright. I usually leave mine off the charger unless the battery is dead and do any charging/sanitizing during the day when I'm not trying to sleep.

  770. There are very few products that I can say I actually love, but this is a product I truly love. This is the third Flexcare Sonicare toothbrush I have had. This particular model, is the Flaxcare+<br /><br />UV Sanitizer: I cannot give a clinical evaluation of the sanitizer, however I can say ever since I've used this toothbrush with the sanitizer I haven't been sick nearly as often. This may not truly mean much, but I do take comfort in the fact that I have the option of killing germs off if I want to sanitize the toothbrush head.<br /><br />With my first flex care, I would remove the head and sanitize it every night. My rough handling of the toothbrush when doing this, may have caused some problems and it eventually stopped working. With this model, I tend to remove the brush head once every couple of nights. I am a bit more careful when pulling it off, as you do have to tug it firmly, and it seems to be doing quite well.<br /><br />Travel Case: I travel, and when I do I bring this toothbrush with me. Previously, Phillips provided a soft case with the brush. This one comes with a hard case, which I really really appreciate. I don't have to worry about it getting banged up in my suitcase or travel bag.<br /><br />Battery Life: In terms of battery life, the previous models would last approximately 2 weeks. I still find, that this one lasts around two weeks as well (maybe a bit longer). It says it can last up to three weeks, however my case I'm using the standard cleaning mode versus the other modes the brush collapse. I believe you might get better battery life using some of the other modes the brush possesses, so Phillipsis not misleading anyone with battery life claims. As always, your mileage may vary based on your use.<br /><br />I have to say that being able to travel without having to bring a power cord is great. I went to Europe twice with this brush and not having to worry about bringing a charger and dealing with odd international outlets was a huge plus. It lasted the 2 weeks I was there without issue. Aside from that, the worst case scenario, if you do drain the battery fully, is that it becomes \\"toothbrush\\" vs. a \\"Sonicare Toothbrush\\", until charged again.<br /><br />Options: There are a couple different brush head types that you can use with this particular model, I tend to use the standard longer brushes. Some may like to use the short brush heads that they offer, but I find it doesn't make sense to use the smaller heads unless you have a specific need for them. This brush also offers a few brushing modes so that you can select what suits you best. As I've said, I use the clean mode almost all the time. The sensitive mode is okay, even though I consider myself to have sensitive teeth, I didn't find it necessary to use that particular mode. Once I got used to the brush, the cleaning mode was absolutely fine.<br /><br />What My Dentist Says: Excellent. That's the word I hear. I get regular checkups, and I've had no degradation in my teeth or any of the work that I've had previously done since I began using this product. I have traditionally been a firm brusher, putting a bit more pressure on the brush than necessary, but I don't find myself being that way with this brush. I feel it is doing the work for me so I treat my teeth a bit better, and unconsciously so. It's a truly great product.
  771. This replaced our old Sonicare and it is great.<br />No more mold collecting in the base in this new design.
  772. I had gum issues and this toothbrush not only helps me get to the hard to get places, but also messages my gums...

(surprisingly that's the second time I've used that sentence today.)

  793. For the actual toothbrush I would give it 5 stars for ease of use, features, and ability to clean teeth. The tip (where the brush heads connect to the toothbrush) came loose and started to make a loud noise and rattling around. This seems to be a slight design flaw with this model. There is a newer Sonicare Toothbrush available (The DiamondClean) and it is possible they fixed the issue in that model.

  799. I purchased this item after my last Sonicare died. That Sonicare was wonderful - long lasting, thorough. A wonderful device.<br /><br />Enter the Flex Care 2. Looked good, seemed to work. A $140 dollar winner But then, after less that one month post purchase, we went on vacation for a month, leaving the base unit behind, taking only the travel charger with us. When we returned home, the base unit, with Sanitizer, would not turn on. The push button \\"switch\\" only worked intermittently and would not stay on for a full sanitizing cycle, let alone a recharge. We contacted the Phillips customer service and they walked us through the tier one fixes; check the bulb, check the switch - the whole deal, and nothing helped. This was on February 28, 2012. They were very kind and helpful and allowed that they would ship a new unit along with a return shipping label (for the broken unit) immediately. We should watch out Email for a confirmation, upon shipping, within two weeks.<br /><br />Two weeks later, we called back and they advised the product is on back order but would be shipped within two weeks.<br /><br />Two weeks later, no product, no contact, so we called back. New customer service agent who sadly announced, the product is on back order, but would be in and shipped ... in two weeks.<br /><br />Two weeks later, we called again - no product available, but it would be in and shipped ... in two weeks. At this point, we requested our money back and were informed that isn't possible. The agent said that this time, for sure, the new unit would be available and shipped by April 23. We said we didn't believe it and just wanted our money ($148) back. The agent said he was sorry, but there was nothing more he could do and severed the connection.<br /><br />I am now stuck with a piece of junk toothbrush and no apparent chance of collecting on the guarantee. There is no way to get it repaired (the company says no - they will only replace it). The item has been discontinued and the warranty is being ignored. We are out $148 and have a minimally useful toothbrush system. And have no indication that things will get any better.<br /><br />This is our third and final Phillips Sonicare System. I don't know what has happened, but it is no longer the product it used to be. There its no customer support and no recourse. We are stuck with junk and cannot get it fixed. Our only hope is that we can warn you folks, before you make the same costly blunder we did.<br /><br />UPDATE 4-13-12<br /><br />Today, we received a new (or refurbished) \\"sanitizing unit\\" and recharger for our defective Sonicare Flexcare+ Also enclosed was a prepaid return FedEx address label, to return the defective unit.<br /><br />Hopefully, this ends our saga. We still won't be purchasing another anytime in the future, but it is somewhat reassuring to have actually had the guarantee fulfilled.

  812. We bought ours around March 2011. In January the UltraViolet light quit working. I checked the bulb and it was fine. I called Phillips warranty service and they had me do all the things I had already done to test it, but being in IT I went ahead and did them again. Warranty repair said that they did not have any base units in stock but would send me one in 4 to 5 weeks. Sure enough about a month later we got a package. It was the handle, not the base unit with the UltraViolet light and it wasn't even the right model of toothbrush handle. I called warranty service again. They apologized and gave me a return address to send the toothbrush handle back and explained that they were currently out of stock on the base unit. After another month we got the base unit and it worked fine for about 2 months. The UltraViolet light stopped working again! By now, it is out of warranty. I looked at the door and in the upper left there is a tab that sticks out. The tab goes into a slot on the base which activates a micro switch. I stuck the end of the lever for some nail clippers into the opening and heard a click. The light now works.

I have no idea how an issue like this could arise from a company that has been using inductive chargers for a long time. If this is the level of engineering I can expect from Philips, I don't foresee buying any products from this company again.<br /><br />Given the quality of the batteries being used (NiMH), I have to wonder if failure is part of their business model.

Philips gets five stars for service and quality.

  830. [For full disclosure, I am actually evaluating the \\"PROFESSIONAL\\" HX6992/10, obtained from my dentist. It appears that the main difference between the units is about $57.]<br /><br />I have used my unit for a couple of years and from the very beginning, my checkups have shown definite improvements. However, during that same time, I have had to obtain three new handles, all for the same reason: the metal pin holding the brush on came out. Fortunately, each time the handle was replaced under warranty, but just for the inconvenience, I had to deduct a star.<br /><br />The work-around solution is simple: put the brush on carefully, lubricating with water if it seems a little too tight, and making sure not to try to push it all the way to the top of the handle (there is supposed to be a small gap). Then, DON'T REMOVE THE BRUSH until you plan to replace it with a new one.<br /><br />Someone else in your household needs to use the brush? Buy a second unit, or at least another handle. The battery charge is ample enough to rotate several handles on one charger.<br /><br />Need to sanitize the brush? Run the brush a few seconds in a half-cap of antiseptic mouthwash. I have not seen any data on the effectiveness of the ultraviolet light on germs on the brushes, especially at the base of the bristles where they would likely to grow, but I am pretty sure that any intensity strong enough to kill germs aren't doing anything to help to the longevity of the nylon brushes. Besides, we have used \\"unsanitized\\" toothbrushes for generations, and I don't recall any pandemics blamed on the practice.<br /><br />Afraid of other contamination or damage in the bathroom environment? Keep the bristles covered with the plastic cap that came with the brush.<br /><br />OK, now that we have resolved the issue of a weak handle, as well as uv bulb burn-out issues others have reported, one may ask \\"if we are not going to use the sanitizer, why pay for it? Why not go to a cheaper system? \\" And those are valid questions.<br /><br />Of course, this brush as more modes than most, but are they really necessary? Gum Care is actually an extended Clean. How tough is it to just push the button again at the end of the two minute Clean cycle? Refresh is a shortened Clean. I guess you can figure how to handle that... The bottom line is that most of these modes are just modifications of others, much like all those \\"cycles\\" found on most washing machines.<br /><br />Yes, other systems are available with a much smaller base with toothbrushes whose Clean cycle works just as well. However, if you find that your dentist or hygienist can sell you this unit for a hundred bucks, you might find it hard to beat that price a smaller unit.d those are valid questions.<br /><br />Of course, this brush as more modes than most, but are they really necessary? Gum Care is actually an extended Clean. How tough is it to just push the button again at the end of the two minute Clean cycle? Refresh is a shortened Clean. I guess you can figure how to handle that... The bottom line is that most of these modes are just modifications of others, much like all those \\"cycles\\" found on most washing machines.<br /><br />Yes, other systems are available with a much smaller base with toothbrushes whose Clean cycle works just as well. However, if you find that your dentist or hygienist can sell you this unit for a hundred bucks, you might find it hard to beat that price a smaller unit.

My teeth were significantly whiter in 2 minutes than they were in 10 minutes with a manual toothbrush. Coffee stains are no match for the Sonicare. This was a luxury purchase when I bought it while in school. It was, and continue to be, one of the best purchases I've made for myself. UPDATE [1/27/13]: Still going strong!! Everything is still working great!! UPDATE [1/1/17]: I am amazed that it has held up for this long. Still great, very reliable.
  841. Has anyone found a good supplier for the bulbs that fit into the UV compartment? That is the most frustrating part of this device. You would think that these bulbs would be available at a local store such as Target or Walmart, but no. In fact, I don't think Phillips sells them.
  842. My wife has used Philips Sonicare in the past and had encouraged me to give it a try. I eventually did and I think it works extremely well.   847. We realllllly loved this sonic care toothbrush! It was almost one of the first things we bought together after we got married. Sadly, less than a year, I mean months short of being a year, this thing started acting crazy buggy. It would go off by itself when it sat on the base, it wouldn't brush when we needed it to, and it just all around became a huge nuisance. We read some reviews and forums regarding this problem and tried almost everything; letting it completely drain, not use it for a wile, keep it unplugged, etc., but nothing worked. Sadly it has been cast aside and now resides somewhere under our sink for the past few years. No idea why we didn't warranty it, just didn't cross our minds. But on a brighter note, for those months we had it, it was fantastic! Our teeth really did feel much cleaner. There was no way I could brush as fast and consistently as that lil guy did. We have since been using a boring regular toothbrush. Our mornings and nights have never been the same.

This is suppose to be the MB of toothbrushes & at one time, it was. It lasted 5-6 years but Sonicare got greedy. The brushes were reasonable then as well. I really feel something of this price should last more than 1 1/2 years. I hope the competition gets the message that Sonicare is going down hill fast.   852. I wanted to submit a review I recently submitted to Phillips. They asked me to rate the product. My review was rejected as not meeting their guidelines. Here are their guidelines: (if anyone can see where I was remiss, please point it out to me. I think they don't want to publish something that points out such a big problem with their units. But, I am open to critique. Please note, they specified the model, which was the newest (the one featured here), on their form, so I did not need to repeat it.<br /><br />Philips values your feedback!<br />When writing your review, please consider the following guidelines:<br /><br />Focus on the product and your individual experience using it<br />Provide details about why you liked or disliked a product<br />All submitted reviews are subject to the terms set forth in our Terms of Use<br />We reserve the right not to post your review if it contains any of the following types of content or violates other guidelines:<br /><br />Obscenities, discriminatory language, or other language not suitable for a public forum<br />Advertisements, \\"spam\\" content, or references to other products, offers, or websites<br />Email addresses, URLs, phone numbers, physical addresses or other forms of contact information<br />Critical or spiteful comments on other reviews posted on the page or their authors<br /><br />Now: HERE WAS MY REVIEW<br /><br />Unit unreliable, stops working properly after few months.<br /><br />I purchased three different model Sonicares over the past 7 years, approximately. The only one that still works is the oldest one. After 7 years, it is still working. Possibly it was superior to the current models. The 2nd model I purchased, with multiple options, had two problems. First, the head began wobbling shortly after purchase (from my dentist). I was told by the receptionist that was a common complaint from the patients who purchased it. Sonicare replaced it. Shortly after that, the handle stopped working. The timer or electronics quit. I was told by a Sonicare customer service rep that the internal batteries only last 1 to 5 years. I could understand 3 to 5 years, but ONE? For $129 dollars plus tax?Even at the $100 plus tax my dentist charged with discount, TOO MUCH! The warranty lasts for 2 years, and with the current model, you'll probably use it. The 3rd unit I purchased (while my 2nd replacement was still working) has had to be replaced twice as well. I think it may still be under warranty, but if I sent it in again, that would be 4 units in one year. The newest one had the same problem with the electronics or timer. It begins by buzzing off and one while in the charging base. The different options might light up or not, the unit may or may not come on. In order to stop the relentless buzzing off and on, the base must be unplugged. The unit, removed, has started all by itself out of nowhere. Shortly after this, death is eminent, and the handle will not turn on at all. My daughters each used the brush twice a day, so it was not getting overcharged. I have also changed the base and plugged it into different outlets. I used the troubleshooting method the first customer service rep had me do. No good on anything. While Sonicare was ready to replace the units, I personally have reached my limit on aggravation, disappointment, and loss of confidence in Sonicare's overall performance. What was once worth $100 plus dollars to me is now not worth replacing. I have two new heads that will not get used, at $18 for the pair. I am looking into alternate toothbrushes, and have found their main competitor to have good reviews, and will give them a try. I went to some consumer rating sites, and found that my problem was one expressed by literally hundreds of other customers. That is when I new this was a Sonicare problem, not a periodically faulty problem. And if I can find this information easily, I would think Sonicare should know about it. Either the design of the newer handles is faulty, or the product is no longer made with the same care as the older models were. Possibly the electronics need to go the way of the dodo bird and Sonicare should stick with what worked so well in the past. Sonicare is a fine instrument...when it is working. However, a spinbrush for $4 plus batteries is better than a non working Sonicare that cost $129, plus tax, and an additional $80 in replacement brush heads every over the course of a year. Sonicare. in my opinion, has ceased to be worth the price they charge. It is a hassle to have to keep having the handles replaced. I want a product that works. Sonicare sends a new handle, so if you have a broken one, under warranty, contact them. I have never had a problem that way. I have returned the broken ones as they request (they send a return label so it is free), but haven't returned the last one that broke. Fedex is 20 minutes away for me, and not worth the gasoline to return it yet again. Sonicare, when your newer units work as well as your older units, I may be back. For now, I will be going with your competitor.
  853. Been using sonicares for almost 12 years and this is the third model I've had. The first two each lasted about 5 years. The first one was still working when I went to the second; I only did it because the brush heads were getting very hard to find. The second model did stop working (gradually got weaker and weaker until it wasn't really doing much more than a regular toothbrush) but that was after 4+ years. So I've come to expect quality for the $$ investment I'm making. However this one, the hx6892/10, has very poor quality. Mine worked great out of the box. But after 13 months it started randomly turning on all on it's own. It would do this on the charger and off the charger. It would wake us up in the middle of the night. I took to hiding it in a pile of sweaters in my closet and closing the door each night so I wouldn't hear it. Then it stopped keeping a charge for long. Then, at 14 months it stopped taking a charge at all and won't turn on.<br /><br />When I looked up my issue I found that MANY people have had the same issue. So this is clearly a product quality issue with the handle. It's disappointing - for the $$ the brush handle should last at least a few years, not one.<br /><br />I have contacted Philips and they were very nice and say they are sending me a new handle. I'd feel better about that, except that I've read that the replacement ones are of no better quality (this isn't a one off bad handle, this is a product quality issue). So I'm just crossing my fingers that it lasts me either 9 months (so that I can get another replacement under the two year warranty) or 2 years (so that I feel like I got my $$ worth).

  870. This toothbrush is incredible. Previously, I had an Oral B electric toothbrush. It worked better than a manual toothbrush, but I was still getting quite a bit of staining on my front teeth from coffee (only one cup a day) and my teeth never felt completely clean after brushings. Obviously, I'm saying this after the fact since I didn't notice it at the time. The Sonicare is incredible. It's not an exaggeration to say that my teeth feel as clean as leaving the dentist office after each use.<br /><br />The different modes are nice, but I usually just stay on the same setting. I rarely change it. The travel charger is nice, and I actually use it daily instead of the larger base with the sanitizer. The UV sanitizer is a nice addition, but it's not something that is absolutely needed. Lastly, the toothbrush is incredibly easy to keep clean. I've owned multiple electric toothbrushes over the years, and I've had problems keeping them clean. There are two ways that this brush is superior in this regard. 1. The brush heads are sealed. This is not the case for all brands, and if they are not sealed it's very easy for water to get inside and start growing nasty things. 2. The joint where the head meats the base is flat. There are no spaces for water to get trapped.<br /><br />Even if this brush worked only as well as a competitor, I would pick it for its ease of keeping clean.
  871. I won't know for sure how this toothbrush is working until my next dental appointment, but after a month my teeth are feeling cleaner and look slightly whiter. I love the quad pacer function, 30 seconds on each part and then you are done in 2 minutes. Battery life is great so far. I love the UV cleaner if for nothing else to protect the toothbrush from creepy crawly things. Only drawback is the recommended weekly cleaning of the device, but small price to pay for a clean brushhead.

The UV light is great, I also like that I can put the brush heads in the case and close it to keep the brushes clean. Speaking of two people using the brush, it arrives with two different brush heads, so my husband uses the larger head, and I use the smaller. Last, but not least; speaking to the real reason for using an electric toothbrush....my teeth and gums are clean and healthy! I can't wait to see my dental hygienist again, to see what she says!

  893. I purchased the Sonicare HX9672 to replace an older model Sonicare toothbrush that seemed to be a favorable home for mold where the brush head connected to the handle. The design of this toothbrush is excellent. The brush head is minimalist and attaches quickly and easily. The handle, while thinner than the old model, is very comfortable to hold. The handle has nubs on the bottom that prevent the toothbrush from rolling off the counter while I apply toothpaste to the head.<br /><br />I decided on this particular model because it has the extra Gum Care mode that the lower models do not. You can choose to use the one-minute Massage mode on its own or tack on the end of the normal brushing mode for a three-minute session (Gum Care). The Refresh mode is a nice one-minute version of the normal (Clean) mode. I haven't use Sensitive mode yet, as I just haven't needed it. The brush goes through a 14-use ramp up period to get your mouth used to it.<br /><br />The only feature I wish it had would be the pressure sensor that the Oral B brushes have. However, what tipped me to choose the Philips over the Oral B was the quadpacer internal timer. The brush hesitates every 30 seconds indicating that it is time to move to another area of your mouth. I love not having to watch the clock anymore! Philips suggested quartering of the mouth didn't work for me, so I figured out a brushing pattern that works for me.<br /><br />Included in the box are two heads (one regular, one compact), a countertop charger with UV sanitizer (can sanitize two heads at once), a portable charger, and a travel case (holds one handle and two heads). This kit is certainly designed to be shared between cohabitants.<br /><br />What I did not really expect was that my mouth actually feels cleaner than it did with my old model. We will see what the dentist says, but my mouth feels almost fresh-from-the-dentist clean after brushing.<br /><br />This thing is not cheap, but it does all I want from a toothbrush. The DiamondClean seems like more money simply for a cool design but no more function over the FlexCare+. I'm very happy with this choice.othbrush. The DiamondClean seems like more money simply for a cool design but no more function over the FlexCare+. I'm very happy with this choice.

However, I do like the capability of sanitizing the brushes and I definitely see a difference with the color of my teeth and the clean feeling after brushing. Would I recommend this model, probably not, but I would definitely recommend a model with less settings and a larger base. I will continue to stay with Sonicare.

  947. The brush is great, but I am reducing the review by 1 star because of the cost of the replacement brush heads. Like any device that requires consumables (think water filters in refrigerators with ice makers), the supplies are expensive and you have little choice but to buy from the factory.<br /><br />My experience is that the brush heads wear out after 90 days. Each new one costs about $10 each - and you buy them in packs of multiples, like 6 or 7. So you could see that after a time, the amount spent on replacement heads would exceed the price spent on the original toothbrush.<br /><br />Before you buy any product that requires replace consumables (like toothbrushes, printers, etc.), price the cost of the consumables too, and figure that in to your cost of ownership.

  993. I had one of the original Sonicare toothbrushes and it served me every day for over five years. It was still working when I decided to upgrade! The new model does a great job cleaning your teeth and stimulating ones gums, but the push button that controls the various features is located in a position that is just too easy to bump while holding the toothbrush. Same goes for the on/off switch - it is in the area you grip whilst holding the instrument. Those inconveniences would cause me to give the product a 4-star rating, but the fact that my instrument simply died after 14 months of ownership really bothers me. Is the new model is built more cheaply that the original design? I don't know...but for a nearly $200 investment, it failed far too early.<br /><br />Good News: I contacted Phillips customer service after writing this review and they are sending me a replacement product under warranty. So - I appreciate their support...it was hassle free. They were very easy to work with. I hope the replacement lasts a few years!
  994. Pretty good toothbrush. It took some getting used to as I had been using an Oral B which rotates and this one goes up and down. It seems like it will last, but I only use it once a month! (Just kidding)
  995. I liked this tooth brush a lot. It does an outstanding job cleaning your teeth, and is built sturdy. I brush my teeth in the morning while taking a shower, prior brushes I owned (earlier Oral B models) would malfunction after a few months. However the Sonicare HX6970 has lasted for 20 months (having just recently died).<br /><br />I contacted Philips to process a warranty replacement, and they are sending me a new unit under the two year warranty.
  996. I've had this toothbrush kit for 4 years and have had to replace the toothbrush handle 6 times total by calling Philips support. I live alone and gently use this product without any form of abuse so there's really no reason for the issues I've had with longevity. The various types of handle failure include: no longer accepting a charge, randomly turn on by itself, and will no longer oscillate due to internal mechanism breakage.<br /><br />I rarely leave product reviews, but had to for this particular one so others are aware of the lack of quality within this Philips product - and potentially all Sonicare products . I simply will not ever buy another Philips Sonicare, and will be selling the replacement handle once it's received from warranty support.
  997. This is my 3rd Sonicare toothbrush, and I really like the disinfecting feature of this model. How many times have you brushed your teeth during an illness & wondered if you were simply re-infecting yourself with whatever bug laid you up in the first place?! With this Sonicare model, you need not worry about such things ever again. Other terrific features? It comes with a travel case & charger, so you never have to leave home without it. A typical Sonicare will last several days on a charge anyway, but for those longer trips out of town, you now have the ability to keep your traditional, manual toothbrush at home. Yea!!<br /><br />Additionally, Sonicare toothbrushes guarantee me a quick cleaning & a perfect report of health at the dentist office every 6 months, and the dentist/hygienist alway comments on how great my teeth look. I will never use any other toothbrush!
  998. I was not convinced the other reviews were really accurate when they said it felt like they had just been to the dentist. I will say it is certainly the next best thing and pretty close. My teeth have not felt so smooth since my last dentist appt. It takes a little to get adjusted to it. It tickles the inside of my mouth a little, but not so much that I fall on the ground laughing and can't finish brushing :)

  1001. This device is used by 2 people in the household on a daily basis. The only similar product I have used is a manual toothbrush and I now prefer this one. The way the device charges is great and it does not have to be plugged in ALL the time, the charge lasts a good long time. I like the whole sonic approach to teeth cleaning and this product does a great job. A couple minor things I do not like are the brush color designators they give you in the form of little rubber rings. The rings are 3 drab colors that aren't that much different from each other. I'd think they should be bright blue, red, yellow, green, orange. What you get is dull blue, blue/grey and white (whiskey tango foxtrot?) The second minor thing is the cost of the replacement brushes, insane. The final thing I dislike is the sanitizer. It is a UV light, that I just read not too long ago, contains mercury. There is a warning label on the product, and my bad during research, if I had caught that before hand I would not have bought this particular model. I could live without the sanitizer. I did just fine without one for the last 4 decades. I guess it's no worse than the newer light bulbs. Can't we get away from household mercury? geezus, ok I digress on with the review. The quality is very good and after more than half a year I'm still pleased with the purchase. So it only get 4 stars because of the 3 negatives I mentioned. I would still recommend a Sonicare toothbrush minus the mercury.
  1002. Worked ok for about a year. The prong that holds the brush head became detached so will need to replace unit.

  1004. This toothbrush is really great. It has a UV cleaner and storage space for two heads, so it works well for a couple. It comes with a handy travel case with brush head covers.   1005. Updated as it's still working fine since I reviewed the original toothbrush. Works great. Refill brushes are easy to find at Costco. Teeth feel cleaner than cleaning with a regular toothbrush. I like it has two chargers. I don't use the sanitizer so I use the travel charger. Takes up less space on the bathroom counter. I like the travel case too. It holds the toothbrush and two brushes.<br /><br />Original review:<br />I had my toothbrush a little over a year. Last week I was woken up in the middle of the night by a loud buzzing sound. My toothbrush had turned on and it would not turn off. The button didn't work! It would stay on for two minutes, turn off for a few minutes and then start up again. It finally turned off so I went back to bed. About an hour later it turned on by itself. I had to put it in another room under some clothes so I could go back to sleep. It was weird and very frustrating. In a quiet house this thing sounds loud.<br /><br />It worked fine for a couple of days. Today it started up again and it would stop for a few seconds, but then restart again. I contacted Phillips by chat. The CSR said because it is under the 2-year warranty they will send me another handle with a postage-paid box to send back the defective one. I asked him if this was just a bad batch of toothbrushes and did the current ones have this problem. He replied that all of them are like this when the bottom area gets moisture. I told him that I don't get the bottom wet. I always put the toothbrush back on the charger and it sits on top of my decorative tissue box. There is no way the bottom can get wet.<br /><br />Last year I would have rated this five stars. I like using the toothbrush, but it seems a big price to pay if it is only expected to last two years. The CSR said that even if I have a brand new handle from them, the original warranty date stands.<br /><br />I searched online today and it seems other people have had this same problem. Very frustrating. Scary too when I'm sleeping and all of a sudden the toothbrush starts buzzing and there is no way to turn it off.starts buzzing and there is no way to turn it off.

  1021. I would recommend this toothbrush to anyone. Since I have purchased this toothbrush, the gum recession has not gotten any worse, and my gums are not sore anymore.   1022. I liked it very much. it is very efficient for tooth brushing. it is excellent alternative to ordinary brush. i highly recomend it to every body
  1023. This is a fantastic piece of technology. I waited almost a whole year to review this product so I could give an accurate review so here we go.<br /><br />First things first this is a well crafted device and it feels good in your hands. It works right out of the box (you have to put the toothbrush head on it) and when you first use it your mouth will feel as clean as it does when you leave the dental office after a cleaning. This feeling will last for a few months about 4 to 6 before you have to change the head, (they recommend ever 3 but with the included sanitizer and the easy way they recommend brushing these heads last a long time.) and once you replace the head it starts all over again. I don't think I can go back to the normal toothbrush now that I have spoiled my mouth with this delightful gadget.<br /><br />Included in the box is the sonic toothbrush, 2 heads (one normal sized and one small one), a charging base with an ionic sanitizer, a travel charger, and a carrying case that holds the toothbrush and 2 heads. (also included are a few interchangeable brush base rings that allow you to differentiate whose brush is whose.) Literally this is everything you will ever need short of replacement heads.<br /><br />The sonic brush has 5 modes which accommodate different durations and vibration speeds, so if you are worried whether or not this will offend your sensitive teeth try the sensitive setting and work your way up. My girlfriend did this and now she does the full clean almost every night before bed. ***One thing you should worry about initially is accidentally brushing up against your teeth with the back of the toothbrush*** It will feel offensive at first, especially if you have sensitive teeth but I assure you no damage is done, but that doesn't mean make a habit of it. As you get accustomed to the toothbrush this happens less and less. True story: I chipped a substantial part of one of my front teeth biting my fork at breakfast and had to have an emergency resin filling, I used this on the normal setting that night without thinking and finished without even realizing I had dental work done that day.<br /><br />The build of this device is very solid, which makes sense because it is meant to vibrate at incredible speeds, the Sanitizing charging base on the other hand is not as substantial so be careful to keep this away from your counter top ledge. Battery life on this thing is incredible. I travel for work and sometimes I am away for 2-3 weeks at a time and even though I have never brought my travel charger with me the toothbrush has never died.<br /><br />The only true criticism I have is that the price is definitely steeper than what most people are going to be comfortable paying, and from what I am told these things do NOT have an indefinite shelf life. But the Philips customer service is outstanding, so should anything happen down the road I am sure they will do all they can to help you find a solution if one is possible. With the cost of dental work nowadays I see this toothbrush as insurance against cavities. It is worth every penny I paid for it. Literally it whitened my teeth over time, reduced the plaque that had built up from poor prior brushing/ flossing, and when used in conjunction with the waterpik water flosser took years of poor dental hygiene off of my teeth.<br /><br />I highly recommend this product. I am extremely satisfied with it and I know you will be too.
  1024. Works very well to clean my teeth that the normal toothbrush won't. Battery lasts over 2 weeks on once a day use. Replacement heads can be pricey but i feel that this device helps me take better care of my teeth - and probably reduces the visits to the dentist.
